abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Because AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS) are diverse, dynamic, and evolve continuously, they require massive continuous investment to enable ongoing discovery and adaptation merely to prevent backsliding.

sec.p: Because AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS) are diverse, dynamic, and evolve continuously, they require massive continuous investment to enable ongoing discovery and adaptation merely to prevent backsliding. Major advances in science and engineering are necessary to realize the vision of equitable, inclusive, sustainable AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS), but they are not sufficient, as human institutions and behaviors fundamentally mediate the translation of scientific discoveries into the sorts of impacts the world needs from its AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS) over the coming decades.

Too many candidate innovations exist for us to enumerate in great detail here.1 And surely many more innovations not presently (widely) anticipated will emerge serendipitously or strategically in the years ahead. We know, however, that a tremendous range of options exist, spanning the full range of AVCsValue chains, from input suppliers, through retailers and food serviceRestaurantsfirmsFirms (Herrero et al. 2020). Figure¬†1 shows that amongst the domains of cellular and digital agriculture, food processingProcessing and safety, health, and resource use efficiency, many potentially disruptive technologies span the whole AVC. Digital innovationsTechnologyinnovation are especially cross-cutting and numerous. From applications of molecular printing, artificial intelligenceDigital technologiesmachine learning, roboticsDigital technologiesrobot(s, ic, ics), and the Internet of Things, all the way to biodegradable coatings, new drying methods, personalized food, and the circular economyCircular economy, all could have meaningful impacts through AVCs. The likely impacts and suitability of any of these inevitably vary among contexts. We take comfort in knowing that an ever-growing pipeline of innovations could be applied in different combinations to solve particular local problems. This diversity of innovations already under development or in various stages of adaptation and diffusion demonstrates that multiple entry points exist to transform AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS) (Box 1: Prioritizing Interventions).Fig. 1
Promising emergent technologies span the AVC
(Adapted from Herrero et al. 2020)

Scientific breakthroughs generally take a significant time to incubate and evolve into more than prototypes for wider application. For example, variants of controlled environment agricultureControlled environment agriculture (CEA), 3D printingProcessing of foods using AVC waste materials, and drones have each been under development for decades already. Private R&DResearch and development investments typically take 5‚Äì15¬†years to generate discernible payoffs and public and philanthropicPhilanthropyR&DResearch and developmentfundingFinance, which is typically targeted at more basic scientific questions, averages 15‚Äì25¬†years to peak return (Chavas et al. 1997).

Nevertheless, the pipeline is healthy and ever expanding. The innovationTechnologyinnovation pipeline is also increasingly well supported by private venture capital that financesFinance an entrepreneurial ecosystem of start-up companies in the agri-food space, perhaps especially for digital agri-food technologies (Graff et al. 2020).

The innovationsTechnologyinnovation we studied exhibit a wide range of technological readinessTechnologyreadiness, from innovationsTechnologyinnovation already being implemented in multiple locations and sub-sectors to ones that remain targets for basic science research (Fig.¬†2). A portfolio approach is necessary when thinking about the array of options. Some innovations could have very specific niches, others could be implemented in large domains. Some could have small impacts, others very large ones, as well as a variety of costs and time for implementation. Virtually all will require some‚Äîbut differing types‚Äîof adaptation to suit specific AFSAgri-food systems (AFS) contexts.Fig. 2
Technological readinessTechnologyreadinessof future agri-food systemsAgri-food systems (AFS) technologies
(Adapted and expanded from Herrero et al. 2020)

Note, too, that the most promising innovations are not solely, or even primarily, scientific breakthroughs or engineering advances. Many key ‚Äúchange accelerators‚Äù‚Äîto use Herrero et al.‚Äôs (2020) term‚Äîwill be sociocultural, policy, or institutional innovations because ‚Äútransformation is also a deeply political process with winners and losers, which involves choices, consensus as well as compromise about new directions and pathways. Powerful players within agri-food systemsAgri-food systems (AFS) have strong incentives to maintain the status quo and their current markets share‚Äù (Herrero et al. 2020, p. 267). At the same time, lucrative opportunities exist for those players that choose to help lead AFSAgri-food systems (AFS) transformation, aligning their purpose (and fortunes) to broader societal interests. Some novel organizational forms (e.g., B corporations) directly embrace such opportunities, but even some that follow more traditional organizational forms (e.g., publicly-traded, multinational corporationsFirms) are exhibiting real leadership with the expectation that this will bring both social and financialFinance reward.

Significant differences of perspectives exist among experts concerning the potential and desirability of scientific/technological innovationsTechnologyinnovation now emergent. In the process of creative destruction of innovation, inevitably some people see progress, while others justifiably worry about prospective harms. There are sure to be unrealized aspirations, unanticipated consequences, predictable problems, and unforeseen obstacles, just as there will be major breakthroughs, some of them scientific, some of them sociocultural or political. Pluralism, intellectual curiosity, and healthy skepticism are paramount in advancing beneficial innovation. Innovation within AVCsValue chains is therefore far more than merely a scientific or commercial or technological matter. InnovationTechnologyinnovationis a sociopolitical phenomenon requiring ongoing consultation and monitoring if we are to navigate successfully towards the SDGsSustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the longer-run design objectives of AVCsValue chains that promote healthyDiet(s)healthy diets, equitable and inclusive livelihoodsIncome, environmental and climate sustainabilitySustainability, and resilienceResilienceto shocksDisastersand stressorsDisasters.

Given these various pressures confronting AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS) now and in the future, what AVC innovations are most likely to induce healthier diets; more sustainable and resilient production, processingProcessing, and distribution systems; and most equitable and inclusive livelihoodsIncome? Our panel identified scores of options that appear especially promising in different contexts, in distinct AVC segments, and at different time horizons. We start with four cross-cutting innovation spaces‚Äîdigital, financeFinance, social protectionSocial protection, and civic engagementEngagement‚Äîbefore moving to innovations more anchored in specific AVC stages from farm- and fisheries-based primary production through supply chainValue chains intermediaries (e.g., manufacturers, processors, and retailers), to consumer-level health and nutritionNutrition innovations. Because of the deep heterogeneityHeterogeneityamong AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS) and the considerable uncertainty around expected impacts‚Äîespecially among innovationsTechnologyinnovation in the early stages of technological readinessTechnologyreadiness‚Äîwe make no attempt to rank among these. Moreover, we do not claim to offer a comprehensive listing, given the rapid pace of new discovery in the agri-food space. The sheer volume of promising innovationsTechnologyinnovation illustrates, however, that technological options are abundant. The key constraints relate to adapting and scalingScalinginnovationsTechnologyinnovation to achieve intended impacts, satisfactorily addressing unintended impacts, and setting the right incentives for beneficial innovations to emerge at sufficient pace and scale to transition AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS) towards HERS outcomes while we have time to skirt calamity.

sec.title: Box 1: Prioritizing interventions for climate-smart agri-food systems*
sec.p: Technologies will have different impacts on the attainment of different AFS-related SDGsSustainable Development Goals (SDGs). This is crucial, as different countries‚Äîor regions within countries‚Äîhave achieved different levels of progress towards the different goals. Different countries might, therefore, preferentially focus on making more progress on some goals than others.

As an example from a climate-smart lens, a Delphi panel of experienced agricultural, food, and global changeTechnologychange scientists from around the world ranked the technology list from Herrero et al. (2020) on readinessTechnologyreadiness, adoption potential, and potential impact. Several technologies seem to balance readinessTechnologyreadiness, adoption potential, and impacts. The top ten ranked innovationsTechnologyinnovation include four technologies relating to replacement food and feed for humans, livestockLivestock, and fishAquaculture: plant-based substitutes, insectsInsects, microalgae and cyanobacteria, and seaweed. Driven in large part by concerns about the harmful net environmental impacts of the livestockLivestock sub-sector and how incomeIncomeand population growthPopulation growth might magnify that damage, many promising efforts are underway attempting either to meet the growing demand for animalDiseaseanimal products by providing alternative proteinMacronutrientsprotein(s) sources that do not rely on livestockLivestock or to reduce livestock‚ÄôsLivestock impacts on landLand via animalDiseaseanimal nutrient sources alternative to traditional feed crops.

Other top-ten technologies include improved climate forecasts and pestPest(s)/disease early warning that rely on digital advances; circular economyCircular economy approaches for reusing, recycling, and repurposing waste resources to boost food productionFoodproduction while creating new local business opportunities; and vertical farmingControlled environment agriculture (CEA) in confined spaces with no soil or natural light, another way to decouple food productionFoodproduction from the landLand.
*This box draws on material from Herrero et al. (2021).

sec.title: Digital Innovations
sec.p:
The ecosystem of digital agriculture has exploded in recent years, with the emergence of myriad agri-tech and downstream ventures across the Global South and North. The broader digital ecosystem can be envisaged as a ‚Äúdigital agri-stack.‚Äù The foundation is made up of the macro-level enabling environment‚Äîincluding connectivityDigital technologiesconnectivity, humanDiseasehuman capital, and critical data infrastructureInfrastructure‚Äîfunctionality that enables system interoperability, and supporting policies. The second layer is the ecosystem of data and content. At farm level this might consist, for example, of soil and water maps; remote sensing weatherClimateweather data from drones, satellites, and other platforms; farmer profiles; data on animalDiseaseanimal and plant genetics; local market price and plantDiseaseplant disease information alerts; and data from a wide range of sensorsDigital technologiessensors. Finally, the products and services that make use of these first two layers comprise the top layer. The various tools and applications can include distinct and bundledBundle/bundling services spanning agricultural extensionExtension, financeFinance, governmentGovernment(s) support programs, and various advisory services. Figure¬†3 represents this digital agri-stack concept within the specific application domain of small farmers in ruralRuraland traditional AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS). COVID-19COVID-19 has increased the value of digital linkages in the food systemFoodsystems, enabling people to connect to markets and production, and allowing processingProcessing and distribution operations to continue, while reducing the human contact rate of conventional approaches.Fig. 3
The digital agri-stack
(Source Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, Digital Farmer Services Strategy)

Digital technologies have penetrated even into ruralRural and traditional contexts with notable speed, with game-changing innovationsTechnologyinnovation often coming from LMICs. In large part, this is due to the advancement and ubiquity of a key digital infrastructureInfrastructure component: the mobile phoneDigital technologiesmobile phone(s) (increasingly the smartphone) and wireless connectivityDigital technologiesconnectivity (especially as 4G becomes ubiquitous). Mobile phonesDigital technologiesmobile phone(s) have enabled people in AfricaAfrica and South Asia to leapfrog over generations. But there remain significant inequities. Mehrabi et al. (2020) found that 74‚Äì80 percent of farmsFarms of larger than 200 hectares had high-speed 3G or 4G connectivityDigital technologiesconnectivity compared to just 24‚Äì37 percent of farmers cultivating less than one hectare. FarmsFarms with the lowest yieldsYields and where farmers face the most climate-related shocksDisasters and food insecurity had even less digital connectivityDigital technologiesconnectivity. Data costs in AfricaAfrica remain high with less than 40 percent of farmingFarms households having access to the InternetDigital technologiesinternet.

At the same time, digital technologies like mobile banking (e.g., mPESA in Kenya), satellite-based riskDisasters management tools (e.g., index-based livestockLivestock insurance in Ethiopia and Kenya: https://www.drylandinnovations.com/), interactive agricultural extensionExtension (e.g., Digital Green: https://www.digitalgreen.org/), and equipment sharing apps (e.g., Hello Tractor in Nigeria: https://hellotractor.com/) obviate market failures that previously constrained poor, ruralRural populations. These digital solutions typically augment existing in-person networks, like Digital Green‚Äôs partnership with governmentGovernment(s)extensionExtension agents and Hello Tractor‚Äôs engagementEngagement with local entrepreneursFirms. Those local service providers are essential; digital providers can extend their reach but not compensate for their absence or inefficiencies (Jensen and Barrett 2016). Service availability gaps thereby limit the gains to closing the digital divide.

High-speed data connectivityDigital technologiesconnectivityand smartphones in even the most remote ruralRuralcommunities have nonetheless served as key catalysts for new investments of capital and talent into AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS). Affordable data pricing and design features that enable neophyte accessibility (e.g., voice recognition) are other key elements of the stackDigital technologiesstack that enable the full range of stakeholders to take advantage of digital advances. Policies and regulations are also needed to create and protect trustTrust and allow the system to continue growing and evolving. Key to this is establishing and enforcing standards that protect data privacy.

HIGH-SPEED DATA CONNECTIVITY AND SMARTPHONES IN EVEN THE MOST REMOTE RURAL COMMUNITIES HAVE NONETHELESS SERVED AS KEY CATALYSTS FOR NEW INVESTMENTS OF CAPITAL AND TALENT INTO AFSs.The enabling environment of connectivityDigital technologiesconnectivity and confidence facilitates the development and exploitation of critical datasets that then empower the performance of many apps. Some data is collected from users, raising issues of the rights associated with data suppliers and aggregators. Other data can be collected using spectral methods at various scales, including remote sensing from satellites, more locally from drones, and by end users or agents with hand-held devices. Remotely sensed data are increasingly available at ever higher resolution, tagged with metadata to enable their utilization. Analysis of spectral data by machine learningDigital technologiesmachine learning enables inferences that can provide users with useful information, such as rapid and low-cost estimates of key indicators of cropCrops identity and health. Though some of these tools are expensive for small-scale producers today, their costs are reducing quickly and the increasing interoperability of sensorsDigital technologiessensors, data sets, and cloud-based computational tools enables the sorts of productivityProductivity-sustainabilitySustainability synergies that were originally envisioned from‚Äîbut never fully delivered by‚Äîprecision agricultureDigital technologiesprecision agriculture technologies introduced into industrialized AFSs starting in the 1990s (Basso and Antle 2020). The African Cassava Agronomy Initiative (http://acai-project.org/), for example, has brought together data systems, digital interfaces, and analytics to support farmers across a range of channels from mobile apps to paper.

Farmers need such hybrid apps to access reliable, accessible data on soil and weatherClimateweather, for instance. Also, spatially explicit datasets combined with machine learningDigital technologiesmachine learning, for example, can be used to make inferences that are useful to farmers to guide decisions on planting and cropCrops management. Critical datasets for a healthy food systemFoodsystems go beyond that to include data that inform actors and actions that manage food quality and safetyFoodsafety; track and tap laborLabor markets; provide credit and insurance markets; map nutritionalNutrition status; monitor sources of pollution, etc. Data pipelines need to not only source raw data, but crucially, to analyze and transform it so that it can be interpreted and acted upon. These require investment to maintain but benefit everyone, including the private sector.

Important innovation is taking place in areas that are critical to farmer livelihoodsIncome, including farm advisory services, digitally linking market actors more efficiently, and supporting more efficient product aggregation among farmers. Some extensionExtension-based apps enable more precise, efficient, and effective use of seeds and fertilizersFertilizer, while others provide disease diagnostic services for animalsDiseaseanimal, plantsDiseaseplant, and people (e.g., PlantWise, https://www.plantwise.org/). Other applications support peer-to-peer (P2P) learning networks supporting entrepreneursFirms and other service providers who serve as intermediaries in the technical space. Digital capacities can link producers into farmer research networks that collectively build the evidence base (Nelson et al. 2019). Innovative Farmers (https://www.innovativefarmers.org/), for example, is a P2P innovation network that facilitates the building of farmer field groups that have a common challenge to address. Each group is paired with a trained researcher, who guides the members through experimental design and evaluation (e.g., evaluating non-pesticide pestPest(s) control when neonicotinoids were banned in the EU).

Apps also link farmers, intermediaries, and markets, letting farmers understand and navigate pricing, and enabling farmers and intermediaries to more efficiently aggregate products. This has ignited demand for new infrastructureInfrastructure, like digitally enabled warehouses for logistics providers (e.g., Arya, https://aryacma.co.in, which operates over 1.6 million metric tons of digitally enabled agricultural commodity storage across ruralRural India).

Digital technologies are also helping consumers trace the origins of the foods they consume, stimulating new potential behaviors in the marketplace, as consumers discover an array of innovative products and producers. In India, Stellapps (http://www.stellapps.com) is developing a digital layer traversing the country‚Äôs massive dairyLivestock industry, providing dairyLivestock cooperatives and private dairyLivestock processors full transparency across the supply chainValue chains. Blockchain technology can enhance the visibility of producers, and farm-to-fork virtual marketplaces can further enhance traceabilityTraceability. For example, FishCoin (www.fishcoin.co) is supporting and rewarding supply chainValue chains actors who share data that enable full traceabilityTraceability across complex global supply chainsValue chains.

Digital technology is also simply making it easier for consumers and manufacturers to access what they want, which is increasingly a more direct connection to farmsFarms and farmers. In Nigeria, Agriple (www.agriple.com) is connecting farmers with buyers to improve transparency, efficiency, and waste reduction. In China, ecommerce platform Pinduoduo (http://en.pinduoduo.com) has helped more farmers sell online as they turn ecommerce into a social experience that helps consumers learn about farmingFarms practices and get group discounts. In India, Ninjacart (http://ninjacart.com) is disintermediating fresh produce value chainsValue chains, linking farmers directly with shopkeepers and consumers. Similar efforts are also underway across the online grocerySupermarkets sector in India, with direct farmer sourcing for fruitsFruitsand vegetablesVegetables initiated by multiple players vying for dominance, including BigBasket, Amazon, and Zomato. Such digital products and services can reduce scale advantages, broadening access to certificationCertification processes and high-return markets, leveling playing fields for smaller farmsFarms and downstream AVC enterprises, and facilitating more direct P2P and business-to-consumer exchange so as to reduce concentrated power in AVCsValue chains. These initiatives have scaled with the liberalization of telecommunications and agricultural policies, and have also piggybacked on governmentGovernment(s) investments in roads, storage, and logistics services.

In industrialized and consolidated AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS), the public sector publishes key data such as weatherClimateweather and public goods. These data can play an important role in policy design and implementation (Capalbo et al. 2017). Private sector digital tools and technologies have built upon those data and are changing how crops are planted, monitored, harvested, and consumed. The agritech startup ecosystem has driven much of this changeTechnologychange, with large agribusinesses acquiring some of the most successful new ventures to ensure their traditional business models are not left behind. Notably, Monsanto (now Bayer) acquired The Climate Corporation (http://climate.com) in 2013, providing them with a strong digital backbone and products like Climate FieldView, which delivers field-level insights to farmers. In 2017, DuPont (now Corteva) acquired Granular (https://granular.ag) to ensure they, likewise, would have farm management software and precision agricultureDigital technologiesprecision agriculture solutions to provide their farmer customers. The same year also saw John Deere acquire Blue River Technology (http://www.bluerivertechnology.com), a roboticsDigital technologiesrobot(s, ic, ics) startup that had developed ‚Äúsee-and-spray‚Äù technologies for weedWeeds (weeding) control, leveraging computerDigital technologiescomputers/ing vision and artificial intelligenceDigital technologiesmachine learning.

More recently, hyper-funded farmer platforms like Farmers Business Network (https://www.fbn.com) and Indigo (https://www.indigoag.com) have sought to redesign more fundamental aspects of the agricultural economy in the modern advanced, industrialized AFSAgri-food systems (AFS). Farmers Business Network is trying to break the dominance of the Big 4 (Bayer, BASF, Corteva, and Syngenta) in seeds and cropCrops protection chemicals, helping farmers to make data-driven decisions regarding inputs, while also providing access to cropCrops insurance, commodity brokerage, financing, and other services. Indigo, on the other hand, started out developing innovative microbial products but is now focusing more on building a post-harvest marketplace for grainCereals sales, commodity transportation solutions, and a carbonClimatecarbon sequestration platform. Both players are well capitalized, having raised a total of US$571 million and US$1.17 billion from investorsFinance (including US$250 million and US$360 million in August 2020 alone) for Farmers Business Network and Indigo, respectively.

Other notable innovationsTechnologyinnovation enjoying accelerating farmer adoption in more industrialized AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS) in recent years include field-based Internet-of-Things systems integrating sensorsDigital technologiessensors and agronomic algorithms (e.g., CropX, https://www.cropx.com); precision agricultureDigital technologiesprecision agriculture platforms to optimize farm equipment (e.g., Solinftec, https://solinftec.com); and farm roboticsDigital technologiesrobot(s, ic, ics), where startups have initially focused on weedingWeeds (weeding) use cases (e.g., Naio Technologies, https://www.naio-technologies.com, and ecoRobotix, www.ecorobotix.com) but are now beginning to tackle harvesting (e.g., Advanced Farm Technologies, https://www.advanced.farm, as well as Root AI, https://www.root-ai.com), and dairyLivestock parlor management.

EVEN WITH AN ENABLING ENVIRONMENT (CONNECTIVITY AND DATA) AND A RANGE OF APPS, THE PERFORMANCE OF THE DIGITAL AGRISTACK CAN UNDERPERFORM IF THE ECOSYSTEM OF DATA AND INSIGHTS BECOMES FRAGMENTED.Further downstream, we find agritech startups working to improve post-harvest supply chainsValue chains, often focused on creating better market linkages between farmers and buyers. In the American heartland, Bushel (https://bushelpowered.com) has set out to ‚Äúfacilitate clear and simple business between grainCereals companies and growers‚Äù through a mobile application. In California (and other horticulturalFruits regions), Full Harvest (https://www.fullharvest.com) has created a digital business-to-business (B2B) marketplace to help growers sell ugly and surplus fresh produce to food processors and other potential buyers. Imperfect Foods (https://www.imperfectfoods.com) has a similar mission of fighting food wasteFoodwaste but works across grocerySupermarkets categories and delivers ‚Äúrescued foods‚Äù directly to customers‚Äô homes. Finally, GrubMarket (https://www.grubmarket.com) has carved a niche for itself as a farm-sourced version of Instacart, offering food products at wholesale prices to both B2B clients and consumers.

Even with an enabling environment (connectivityDigital technologiesconnectivityand data) and a range of apps, the performance of the digital agristack can underperform if the ecosystem of data and insights becomes fragmented. The adoption of a common technology platform can help AFSAgri-food systems (AFS) actors converge and continue to enhance system performance. An enabling technology platform for any ecosystem has several components. For instance, different tools help us find data (data discovery), translate it into a common form (data transformation) and make it easy to share (data transfer). These services are neutral to content but required to make it easy for individuals and organizations to safely exchange or combine data. FarmStack, currently under development by Digital Green, is developing a decentralized architecture comprised of P2P connectors specifically addressing this last service. P2P connectors ease the data exchange process between partners. Of course, as data are sensitive and valuable assets, data owners want to protect them, and farmers need to have the ability to monetize their own farm and farmer profile information which other third parties can leverage to build their own applications. Therefore, FarmStack is also developing and codifying usage policies that will ease and automate this over time, accelerating the exchange of public and proprietary data to drive collective impact as well as inform policy-makers and research.

One example of a new data layer that could foster the emergence of innovative new products and services throughout AVCsValue chains is the Rockefeller Foundation-supported Periodic Table of Food Initiative (PTFI), a global effort to create a distributed network of labs using standardized methods to populate and continuously update a databaseDigital technologiesdatabase(s) of the full biochemical composition and function of food using the latest mass spectrometry technologies and bioinformatics. The current scientific understanding of food covers, at most, 150 of foods‚Äô biochemical components, typically summarized as sample averages in conventional nutrient composition databasesDigital technologiesdatabase(s). A food systemFoodsystems that supports human and planetary health, however, requires rigorously collated data covering the full range of the tens of thousands of biochemical molecules in food that mediate the relationships between food, diet, health, nutritionNutrition, and the environment. PTFI can enable interoperability of data and democratize the analysis of food with the development of low-cost kits, standards, methods, cloud-based analytical tools, and a self-sustaining, broadly accessible databaseDigital technologiesdatabase(s)‚Äîthe Periodic Table of Food‚Äîthat will include the quantitative and qualitative analysis of foods. These data can better equip AVC actors to personalize diets and promote health for individuals based on specific needs, development stage, age, health status, and other factors, as well as improve agricultural systems for increased environmental sustainabilitySustainabilityand resilienceResilience to various biotic and abiotic shocksDisasters.

An interoperable platform of services can speed up¬†the potential for new insights, services, and products. As already mentioned, a broad range of apps have already emerged, from physical products (e.g., roboticsDigital technologiesrobot(s, ic, ics) and smart sensorsDigital technologiessensors) to human networks (e.g., crowdsourcing production insights or plantDiseaseplant disease surveillance) to conceptual (e.g., a predictive analytics app that helps farmers decide what to plant based on likely weatherClimateweather and market conditions). Future applications will also solve problems where we cannot yet see clear connections at the intersection of agriculture and health, financialFinance services, and human rights, easily integrating data and producing unforeseen relationships and solutions. The barriers to more novel digital innovations in AFSAgri-food systems (AFS) primarily arise from consumer and farmer acceptance. For example, a price premium has emerged for older-model farm machinery in secondhand markets in the US as farmers seek simpler equipment that is cheaper and easier to maintain and to safeguard their privacy from equipment dealers and service providers.

Unintended consequences will almost surely arise from digital innovationsTechnologyinnovation, as with any new technologies. For example, digital marketplaces that help farmers sell ugly or surplus produce may deprive food banks and pantries of an important source of healthy foods to provide their patrons, or they could siphon demand from other growers, thereby depressing prices small farmers receive. Individual-specific data can enable retail or food-service marketing campaigns more effectively targeted to manipulate consumers‚Äô weaknesses or allow agro-input dealers to bundleBundle/bundling inputs and services to extract greater profit by exploiting detailed knowledge of farmers‚Äô behaviors. If too many digital innovationsTechnologyinnovation get locked up in patentsIntellectual property rights, it could slow advances and make IP-protected new technologies unaffordable for lower-income subpopulations. And high-tech solutions can never fully overcome natural inferential limits to generating precise, field- or farm-level information on soils and other key variables that influence farmer decision-making (Schut and Giller 2020).

Digital innovations is one space not struggling to secure adequate private investment right now. Access to adequate financeFinance does not, however, characterize most of the AFSAgri-food systems (AFS) innovation space.

sec.title: Innovative Financing
sec.p: Product and process innovation inevitably requires significant up-front investment. CERES2030 (https://ceres2030.org/) recently estimated that donors need to more than double their annual contributions targeted towards food securityFoodsecurityand nutritionNutrition objectives, increasing them by an additional US$14 billion to 2030. In addition, developing-country governmentsGovernment(s) will need to commit a further US$19 billion each year, just to meet three of the five targets under SDG 2 (zero hunger), with two-thirds of this additional public spending focused on AfricaAfrica (Laborde et al. 2020). This assumes that governmentGovernment(s) and donor spending will crowd-in an extra US$52 billion in private investment annually. This US$85 billion/year estimate is almost surely a lower bound on the scale of financing needed to transition AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS) in the developing world to meet the broader HERS objectives‚Äînot just three of five targets under SDG 2 to 2030‚Äîmuch less the financing needed globally.

Inducing sufficient investment in AFSAgri-food systems (AFS)innovation will require innovations in financeFinance. The resources exist. Global assets under management at the end of 2019 stood at US$89 trillion (Heredia et al. 2020). And with interest rates at historic lows, investorsFinance actively seek promising new investment opportunities. But most capital is allocated by private investors, who presently lack incentives to address environmental or public health externalitiesSpillovers, or to attend to needs in low incomeIncome countries where limited purchasing power and weak institutional and governance frameworks depress commercial potential. To effectively exploit food-demandFooddemand growth over the coming generation‚Äîespecially in sub-Saharan AfricaSub-Saharan Africa where the bulk of additional demand will occur‚ÄîAVC innovations must address pervasive climate, environmental, health, and social justiceSocial justicespilloversSpillovers in order to ensure long-term, sustainable returns. Some recent innovations and a growing pool of capital searching for aligned opportunities show promise for helping foster accelerated AFSAgri-food systems (AFS)R&DResearch and developmentfinanceFinance and for growing investment in AVC innovators committed to advancing HERS-consistent AVC transformation.

Historically, much critical basic science fundingFinance came from governmentsGovernment(s)and philanthropiesPhilanthropy. That was true of the US agricultural revolution of the 1930s‚Äì1950s and of the Green RevolutionGreen Revolutionin AsiaAsiaand Latin AmericaLatin America and Caribbean in the 1960s‚Äì1980s. But outside of a few middle-income countries (Brazil, China, and India) that have invested heavily in agricultural R&DResearch and development due to the strategic importance of the sector to their economies, public investment in agri-food R&DResearch and development slowed dramatically over the 1990s and 2000s (Pardey et al. 2016). Some of this decline was due to complacency in the wake of Green RevolutionGreen Revolution successes, and there has been renewed interest on the part of some donors since the 2008‚Äì2012 global food-priceFoodprice(s) spikes. Most recently, in 2019, multiple bilateral and foundation donors committed to a major expansion of fundingFinance for the CGIAR‚Äîthe main network of multinational agricultural research institutions‚Äîas part of structural reforms to that global agricultural research organization. But public and philanthropicPhilanthropy investment remains woefully insufficient to meet the yawning innovation needs of AVCsValue chains.

Reallocation of current governmentGovernment(s)farm subsidiesSubsidies offer an obvious source for public financeFinancefor AFSAgri-food systems (AFS)innovations. SubsidySubsidies programs in most Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries and in China largely impede, rather than advancePareto, necessary innovations towards more sustainable, resilient, inclusive, and equitable AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS) (OECD 2020; Searchinger et al. 2020). Only one-eighth of total governmentGovernment(s)support of agriculture presently goes to R&DResearch and development, inspection and control systems, and ruralRuralinfrastructureInfrastructure‚Äîthe things that promote beneficial innovation‚Äîas compared to three-quarters provided as financial transfersDigital technologiestransfers to individual producers, mostly in a¬†distributionally¬†regressive manner that reinforces inequalityInequality (OECD 2020).¬†One centerpiece of a strategy to mobilize private financeFinance involves fixing the distorted incentives created by governmentGovernment(s)agriculture subsidiesSubsidies that implicitly promote investment in practices and products that generate serious environmental and health spilloversSpillovers. Agricultural subsidySubsidies reform is politically fraught everywhere but essential to get market signals right to induce investorsFinance to divest from unsustainable and unhealthyDiet(s)unhealthy enterprises. The high-level Financing Nature report emphasizes ‚Äúharmful subsidy reform‚Äù as its top recommendation for mobilizing financeFinance to stem the looming biodiversityBiodiversity/extinctionExtinction crisis (Deutz et al. 2020).

The largest and growing share of agri-food R&DResearch and development investment comes from private firmsFirms (Pardey et al. 2016) (e.g., by machinery, fertilizerFertilizer, and agrochemicalAgrochemicals manufacturers; seed companies; food processors and manufacturers; retailers; and food or third-party logistics enterprises). Their commercial objectives can dovetail nicely with broader societal interests in circumstances where prospective beneficiaries are able, and willing, to pay for improved products and processes, and where effective regulatory oversight or appropriate tax policies limit any negative externalitiesSpillovers that arise from the innovation. Just as private agri-food R&DResearch and development has increasingly dominated the innovation landscape over the past generation (Pardey et al. 2016), so has public awareness that modern AVC innovations commonly lead to uncorrected climate, environmental, health, and social justiceSocial justiceexternalitiesSpillovers and fail to address the needs of the poor, who rarely present a lucrative market to investorsFinance. Simply mobilizing more capital under current financial market designs seems an unlikely path to success.

Innovation in private investment will be necessary to advance beneficial AVC innovation and financeFinance the widespread adoption of innovations. One modest, but important, development is the rise of institutional investorsFinance with a longer-term view on returns. Whether driven by social and environmental concerns, rising concern about the downside riskDisasters of stranded assets, diminishing returns to more conventional assets, or some other motive, private investorsFinance, pensions, and others with decades-long returns horizons are increasingly investingFinance in regenerative agriculture, sustainable forestry and fisheries, green bondsFinance, etc. For example, as of 2019 there was more than US$320 billion under management in assets focused on regenerative agriculture in the US alone (Electris et al. 2019). Equally exciting is the emergence of a robust and growing conservationBiodiversityfinanceFinance movement, mobilized by groups such as the Coalition for Private Investment in ConservationBiodiversity. Conservation financeFinance is developing new financialFinance instruments that are attracting private investment in financially attractive conservationBiodiversity investments (Deutz et al. 2020).

Across the globe the momentum is building around Environment, Social, and Governance (ESG) investingFinance, which offers a set of recognized criteria that value-based investorsFinance can use to deploy capital for sustainable, long-term financialFinance gains that align their principles with those of their shareholders (Boffo and Patalano 2020). While ESG rating methodologies and standards continue to be refined, the broader impact-investingFinance market‚Äîof which ESG is only a part‚Äîhas risen sharply over the last decade, now encompassing at least US$715 billion in assets under management (GIIN 2020). The impact-investing market is widely expected to grow further as evidence mounts on the positive relationship between ESG investment and corporate financialFinance performance (Friede et al. 2015). Many ESG fundsFinance are allocated by specialized asset managers (i.e., Paris-based Livelihoods Funds) that have emerged to pool resources from private companies‚Äîincluding massive AVC corporationsFirms‚Äîfor investments in sustainable agriculture in smallholder farmingFarms communities around the world.

While shifting investor preferences create new opportunities and unlock additional capital, thus far this remains a modest share‚Äîten percent or less‚Äîof global private assets under management and a fraction of the resources required to trigger necessary AVC transformation. The first challenge to overcome is a geographic one. Although international financialFinancemarkets increasingly integrate economies around the globe, investment capital remains anchored to high-income countries by home country bias. Agroecosystems exhibit huge heterogeneityHeterogeneity, however. Place-specific R&DResearch and development is therefore essential as are localized AVC innovators and enterprises to drive adoption of HERS products and services at scale.

ALTHOUGH INTERNATIONAL FINANCIAL MARKETS INCREASINGLY INTEGRATE ECONOMIES AROUND THE GLOBE, INVESTMENT CAPITAL REMAINS ANCHORED TO HIGH-INCOME COUNTRIES BY HOME COUNTRY BIAS.Given that most growth in food demandFooddemand will take place in AfricaAfrica (Box 1 in Chapter 3)‚Äîwhere agri-food productivityProductivity lags and environmental, healthyDiet(s)healthydiet, equityEquity, and inclusionEquity concerns are legion‚Äîthat is the continent most in need of AVC investment capital. GovernmentsGovernment(s) and international donors can help, but catalyzing private investment is essential and currently woefully insufficient. The simple reason is that AfricanAfrica markets are widely perceived as less lucrative and higher riskDisasters than are high-incomeIncome markets, so private investment flows lag far behind where they need to be. The bulk of private agricultural R&DResearch and development investment worldwide is undertaken by a small number of massive firmsFirms; less than two dozen firms accounted for more than 70 percent of global private agricultural R&DResearch and development from 1990 to 2014 (Fuglie 2016). Private agricultural R&DResearch and development in developing countries accounts for only two percent of global R&DResearch and development investment in the sector globally (Fuglie 2016).

We can only increase private investment in agri-food innovation in developing countries by adjusting investorFinance incentives and designing enabling environments to promote and direct investorFinance appetite. Innovative ideas with considerable potential are already being successfully employed. For example, the growing Green, Social, and SustainabilitySustainabilityBondsFinance movement seeks to coordinate major international financialFinance institutions and other significant players in global financialFinance markets to support a framework intended to catalyze ESG investments. The International Capital Market Association (ICMA) has been mandated to develop a set of guidelines and principles for bond market issuers, to ensure that participants deploy and manage raised capital to facilitate and support green, socially-conscious, and sustainable investingFinance.2

Capital markets have already responded positively. Moody‚Äôs projects US$400 billion in global green bond issues in 2020,3 continuing a sharp growth trend of approximate market doubling every 2‚Äì3¬†years. This is likely to trigger additional inflows into underserved markets, such as AfricaAfrica. A landmark agreement signed in September 2019 between Japan‚Äôs Government Pension Investment FundFinance‚Äîthe world‚Äôs largest‚Äîand the African Development Bank (AfDB), supporting inclusive and sustainable growth in AfricaAfrica, led to an oversubscribed US$3 billion AfDB Social Bond that was the largest USD denominated social bond transaction in capital markets when issued in March 2020.

A bottleneck to unleashing the full potential of sustainable financing remains the formalization of coherent, transparent, and standardized definitions of, and ratings for, various classes of projects. Generalized endorsement of taxonomies that can underpin regulations and generate the capacities, instruments, and reporting frameworks to appropriately steer capital flows are important. At the global level, the International Platform on Sustainable Finance (IPSF)‚Äîwhose growing membership currently represents roughly half of the world‚Äôs population and half of global GDP, and which also emits half of the planet‚Äôs GHGsClimategreenhouse gas(es)‚Äîis promoting information disclosure standards, policy frameworks, and a global governance architecture consistent with stimulating private investment and steering capital towards ESG objectives (IPSF 2020). This complements the Harmonized Framework for Impact Reporting for ESG investments endorsed by eleven leading international financialFinance institutions.4 In general, ESG instruments‚Äîand particularly the ‚ÄúGovernance‚Äù component‚Äîare expected to have a significant, positive stimulus impact on private financing for emerging and developing economies where risksDisasters arising from uncertain information quality, unclear institutional frameworks, and weak governance have limited investment to date.

Even as these regulatory frameworks develop within the international public arena to promote private sector investment, businesses are also developing their own certificationCertification processes to signal their values and position themselves to attract both aligned investorsFinance and consumers. The emergence of certified B corporations (B corps)‚Äîa pro-social business form that puts environmental and social performance on par with financialFinance performance‚Äîhas shown promise as a way to internalize the true social costs and benefits of an enterprise‚Äôs activities. B corps are hybrid enterprises that legally commit to third-party environmental and social audits conducted by B Lab, a US-based non-profit organization. In many ways, B corps epitomize social entrepreneurship. But since their emergence as a distinct organizational form in the 2000s, only about 3,500 companies in 74 countries have adopted this form‚Äîincluding significant ones in the AVC space, such as Ben & Jerry‚Äôs, Cabot, Danone North America, and Klean Kanteen‚Äîand these have not yet had a major impact on AVC innovation or investment patterns.5 Greater creativity and innovation remain necessary to mobilize financeFinancefor agri-food R&DResearch and development.

A SIMPLE CHANGE TO PATENT LAWS IN HIGH-INCOME COUNTRIES COULD SIGNIFICANTLY BOOST INCENTIVES TO AGRI-FOOD R&D FOR THE GLOBAL SOUTH.Another class of promising innovations to unlock financing‚Äîparticularly suited to cutting-edge R&DResearch and development‚Äîcomes from advanced market commitments (AMCs), wherein governmentsGovernment(s) or donors guarantee a sufficient scale of remunerative purchases of any innovationTechnologyinnovation that meets pre-specified impact criteria. AMCs aim to induce private investment and ensure subsequent access to the technology by low-incomeIncome users. AMCs have been used successfully for pneumococcal vaccine (Kremer et al. 2020). Many lessons remain to be learned about AMC design, but the pneumococcal experience thus far is estimated to have resulted in 700,000 lives saved at a highly favorable cost/benefit ratio (Kremer et al. 2020). Other innovation incentives (prizes, contests, etc.) likewise show promise (Wagner 2011) and are currently being implemented in the AgResults prize competitions operated by the World Bank and in the Food System Vision Prize sponsored by the Rockefeller Foundation.

Another approach is to modify intellectual property rightsIntellectual property rights. PatentsIntellectual property rights offer inventors a governmentGovernment(s)-sanctioned monopoly in a novel and useful discovery for a period of time in exchange for public release of all the technical details necessary to replicate the innovation. PatentsIntellectual property rights‚Äô lucrative prospective returns lure large investments. Currently, however, the meager prospective monopoly returns to innovationsTechnologyinnovation in orphan crops in low-incomeIncome countries, simple irrigationIrrigation technologies suitable for the Global South, or cropCrops drying technologies for small-scale farmers, etc., result in private under-investment in R&DResearch and development for low-income markets. A simple change to patentIntellectual property rightslaws in high-income countries could significantly boost incentives to agri-food R&DResearch and developmentfor the Global South. The idea is reasonably straightforward (Barrett 2020). In its patentIntellectual property rights application, an inventor would volunteer to dedicate its patentIntellectual property rights to the public‚Äîthat is, forfeit its right to deny licensing to third parties, thereby relinquishing its monopoly supply right‚Äîin exchange for an extensionExtension of an alternate, existing patentIntellectual property rights on a non-essential product, meaning one not needed to safeguard life or essential liberties. For example, a firmFirms with a highly profitable patentIntellectual property rights on treatments for male hair restoration6 might profitably extend that patentIntellectual property rights for several years if, and only if, it were to develop a non-toxic means of eradicating a pestPest(s) like fall armyworm or diseases like East Coast fever or black sigatoka that afflict low-incomeIncome tropical agroecosystems, for which there is likely little commercial profit but great humanitarian benefit (Barrett 2020). The essence of the idea is to induce investment in socially beneficial innovations by firmsFirms that can extract monopoly rents from high-incomeIncome consumers‚Äô demand for luxury products and services7 but that could not easily recoup investments from the new discovery‚Äôs primary intended beneficiaries.

The other challenge to mobilizing financeFinance for beneficial innovation surrounds how to monetize spilloverSpillovers effects on the environment and third parties, including future generations. Partly, such concerns motivate public and philanthropicPhilanthropy investment. But regulation and tax policy can also reduce the returns on activities that generate negative externalitiesSpillovers. Combined with subsidiesSubsidies to those actions that generate positive externalities, the regulation and tax policies together can correct market failures and induce greater pro-social private R&DResearch and development, as well. Hence the value of taxesTaxes on unhealthyDiet(s)unhealthyhighly processedProcessing foods and emissions of GHGClimategreenhouse gas(es) and other pollutants, and subsidiesSubsidies for on-farm conservationBiodiversity, investment in renewable energy fixed capital, and employment of workers from marginalized subpopulations.

Some HERS objectives can be advanced through regulatory requirements on banks, insurers, and publicly traded corporationsFirms to disclose environmental and social impacts of investments as a fiduciary duty to investors and society. The stronger disclosure frameworks being promoted to induce high standards of ESG performance, and the certificationCertification and reporting instruments being established to increase the confidence of impact investorsFinance can, likewise, increase the efficiency and targeting of tax and subsidySubsidies incentives. When combined, for example, with markets to facilitate emissions trading and improved technologies for monitoring and verifying nutrient fluxes‚Äîand enhanced screening, verification, and tracking of investments and innovationTechnologyinnovation impacts facilitated by digital innovation and artificial intelligenceDigital technologiesmachine learning‚Äîthe potential to monetize the provision of environmental services can be a powerful inducement to increase beneficial investment in HERS-consistent R&DResearch and development and enterprise.

sec.title: Innovative Social Protection Instruments
sec.p: Transformation inevitably brings dislocation. Facilitating inclusive transformation requires effective social protectionSocial protectioninstruments to protect those who stand to lose out from creative destruction. Otherwise, the human costs of innovation become grave and can prompt damaging backlash and associated sociopolitical instabilityConflict (Barrett 2013). We witness this today in the rise of nationalist, populist political movements worldwide at a time of significant technological changeTechnologychange that has concentrated gains among a privileged few while destabilizing many.

The Nobel Laureate Amartya Sen famously wrote, ‚ÄúStarvation is the characteristic of some people not having enough food to eat. It is not the characteristic of there being not enough food to eat‚Äù (1981, p. 1, emphasis in original). If we are to advance equityEquity, inclusionEquity, and healthyDiet(s)healthy diets objectives, then demand-side innovations must accompany the supply-side ones that usually attract most of the attention in discussion of agri-food systemsAgri-food systems (AFS). Perhaps paramount among these are enhanced coverage and effectiveness of social protectionSocial protection instruments.

Social protectionSocial protection instruments aim to protect individuals from unnecessary human suffering of any sort, including diet-related ill health and extreme povertyPoverty. The idea behind social protectionSocial protection is to catch people who fall into hardship and assist them until they are able to sustain themselves again, thereby both preventing descents into povertyPoverty traps in which deprivation becomes self-reinforcing and encouraging productive riskDisasters-taking by instilling confidence that one will be supported in the event of misfortune (Barrett et al. 2019). Social protectionSocial protection instruments represent the main demand-side innovations essential to AFSAgri-food systems (AFS) transformation.

Social protectionSocial protection programs of various types have expanded dramatically over the past generation or so‚Äîand especially during the COVID-19COVID-19 pandemic (Gentilini et al. 2020a)‚Äîwith different purposes and impacts. But as shown in Fig.¬†4, food assistanceFoodassistance programs remain the dominant mode in LMICs, covering at least 20 percent of the population‚Äî1.5 billion people‚Äîin 108 countries, more than double the total covered by conditional and unconditional cash transfersDigital technologiestransfers and nearly five times the population covered by school feedingFoodassistance programs (Alderman et al. 2017). Bastagli et al. (2016) found that at least 130 LMICs have at least one unconditional cash transferDigital technologiestransfers, and about 63 have at least one conditional cash transferDigital technologiestransfers. The International Labour Organization, nonetheless, estimates that only 45 percent of the global population is effectively covered by at least one social protectionSocial protection benefit and that developing countries alone need to investFinance an extra US$1.2 trillion to close their annual social protectionSocial protection financing gap (ILO 2020).Fig. 4
Social protectionSocial protection program coverage among 108 low- and middle-incomeIncome countries
(Data source Alderman et al. 2017) (CCT‚Äâ=‚Äâconditional cash transfer; SA‚Äâ=‚Äâsocial assistance; UCT‚Äâ=‚Äâunconditional cash transfer)

Myriad forms of social protectionSocial protection exist. Some provide a substitute for incomeIncome and may include cash and in-kind transfer programs to directly boost incomesIncome through policies (e.g. universal basic incomeSocial protection, employment guarantee schemes, laborLabor-intensive public works programs). Others reduce the cost of essential goods (e.g., food subsidiesSubsidies, vouchersFoodassistance, food stampsFoodassistance). Still others provide mechanisms to ensure access to essential public services (e.g., school scholarships, fee waivers for health care services, universal ruralRural broadband access). Some of the most widespread and politically popular social protectionSocial protection programs are food assistanceFoodassistance programs that aim to directly enhance food access (Alderman et al. 2017)‚Äîfor example, through the provision of public works employment paid in food, increased purchasing power (through the provision of food stampsFoodassistance, coupons, or vouchersFoodassistance), and food-based relief interventions (through the direct provision of food to households or individuals). Some are carefully targeted in an attempt to focus coverage on specific subpopulations only (e.g., girls, orphans, and vulnerable children; the elderly; refugees; school children). Some programs only confer benefits conditional on participants engaging in specific, mandated behaviors (e.g., keeping children enrolled in school, contributing laborLabor effort to public works programs, etc.)

Figure¬†5 depicts how different social protectionSocial protection programs fit together, depending on the targeting, mode, and conditionality of transferDigital technologiestransfers. Many countries operate multiple such programs (e.g., the public distribution system and the national ruralRural employment guarantee scheme in India, two pillars of that nation‚Äôs broader welfare system) as illustrated in Fig.¬†5.Fig. 5
How different social protectionSocial protection measures fit together
(Adapted from Gentilini et al. 2020b)

Given the variety of social protectionSocial protection programs already in use across most countries in the world, why is innovation needed in this space? Three main issues need attention. Each of these involves some combination of technical advances based on science and engineering. Mainly, however, innovations in social protectionSocial protection require social support and political will to investFinance in equitable, inclusive outcomes. Particular attention is needed to overcome longstanding, systemic discriminatory access on the basis of ethnicity, gender, race, religion, etc., that exists‚Äîbut manifests differently‚Äîin virtually all countries. Active efforts are commonly needed to address underlying inequities through targeting and differentiation in benefits.

PARTICULAR ATTENTION IS NEEDED TO OVERCOME LONGSTANDING, SYSTEMIC DISCRIMINATORY ACCESS ON THE BASIS OF ETHNICITY, GENDER, RACE, RELIGION, ETC., THAT EXISTS‚ÄîBUT MANIFESTS DIFFERENTLY‚ÄîIN VIRTUALLY ALL COUNTRIES.First, abundant evidence suggests that food-related social protectionSocial protection programs improve beneficiaries‚Äô lives, particularly for households that suffer from a food securityFoodsecurityshockDisasters (Behrman and Hoddinott 2005; Behrman and Skoufias 2006; Alderman et al. 2017; Hidrobo et al. 2018). But demonstrated food-related gains have been concentrated mainly on caloric acquisition and food expenditures (Hidrobo et al. 2018). The impacts on dietary diversity and quality, perhaps especially among children, remains mixed (de Groot et al. 2017). For example, a meta-analysis evaluating 15 different safety-net programs found that the impacts on child growth were insignificant overall, but at the same time, demonstrated impacts on growth in Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, Mexico, South Africa, and Sri Lanka (Manley et al. 2012; de Groot et al. 2017). Conditional cash transferDigital technologiestransfers and food transfer or subsidySubsidies programs in Mexico, Egypt, and the US improve elements of diet quality, food insecurity, povertyPoverty, and undernutritionUndernutrition outcomes (Hawkes et al. 2020). Indeed, some social protectionSocial protection programs inadvertently increase diet-related riskDisasters of obesity and non-communicableDiseasenon-communicable diseases (Kronebusch and Damon 2019; Hawkes et al. 2020). So the first direction of necessary innovation is to redesign food-related social protectionSocial protection programs around healthyDiet(s)healthy diets objectives, rather than merely avoiding hunger and undernourishmentUndernourishment. This could occur through improved food reformulationReformulation, food assistanceFoodassistance programs more restrictedFoodtrade to nutrient-rich (rather than calorie-dense) foods, or other methods. Mainly, it requires political will and a change in mindset.

Second, although social protectionSocial protection programs‚Äô coverage appears widespread, huge numbers of people slip through the safety netsSocial protection, especially marginalized populations in remote areas. Errors of inappropriate exclusion can be reduced through several directions of innovations. First, as climate, disease, trade, and other risksDisasters loom larger, we need improved early-warning systems to trigger prompt expansion of social protectionSocial protection programs to meet changing and growing needs. Some of this can be accomplished through advances in remotely sensed or crowd-sourced data collection, combined with advanced analytics to generate accurate, near‚Äìreal time indicators of evolving needs and food supplyFoodsupply conditions (Jean et al. 2016; Fanzo et al. 2020; Lobell et al. 2020; Porciello et al. 2020; Yeh et al. 2020).

Systems could be developed to improve the adaptive management of response form‚Äîas sometimes households most need cash to meet varied food, health, and other needs, and at other times (e.g., in hyperinflationary environments) in-kind food transfers can provide essential protection against food-priceFoodprice(s) spikes. Continued advances in reliable, low-cost, secure transmission of mobile cash and vouchersFoodassistance can also accelerate response to safeguard healthyDiet(s)healthy diets for vulnerable populations, especially in conflictConflict-affected areas where delivery is costly and dangerous, and rapid response is of greatest humanitarian importance. Finally, diverse social protectionSocial protection programs remain remarkably unintegrated. Digital and other technologies can more effectively network large-scale programs (e.g., those provided by national governmentsGovernment(s)), with more informal, local, and/or private food assistanceFoodassistance programs (e.g., through food banks and pantries), automating enrollment and distributing resource demands more effectively.

Third, the increasing digitization of social protectionSocial protectionprograms poses real risksDisastersto individual privacy and dignity. Biometric methods can help reduce fraud to ensure prudent use of scarce public resources. But when only marginalized populations are subjected to facial, fingerprint, or other recognition tools, or if it is only beneficiaries whose personal data are made available to private vendors and service providers that may prey on underinformed consumers, programs intended to help the vulnerable can become tools of exploitation, discriminationEquity, and disadvantage.

sec.title: Innovations in Civic Engagement and Policy
sec.p: The same risksDisasters of dislocation that necessitate innovations in social protectionSocial protection equally demand advances in civic engagementEngagement and the crafting and conduct of public policy. AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS) are both highly complex and evolving very rapidly. Technical innovations too often tend to be ‚Äúpushed‚Äù (i.e., originating from R&DResearch and development and effective marketing of new discoveries) rather than ‚Äúpulled‚Äù (i.e., from citizens asking for new ways of doing things). And the silo-ed organization of innovation and governance ecosystems too often lead to the emergence of new products and practices developed from a reductionist, rather than a systemic, perspective to meet narrow commercial, political, or scientific aims rather than assessing synergies and tradeoffs more broadly to anticipate whether innovations will likely prove ‚Äúsystem positive‚Äù in terms of their total impacts through positive and negative feedback pathways. The result is too often unintended, but rather predictable, adverse consequences or unfulfilled promises. The fact that our AFSs are growing ever more complex and, at the same time, the future is becoming more uncertain requires new ways of thinking to achieve ‚Äúsystem positivity,‚Äù and underpinning knowledge becomes increasingly key (though, as discussed below, knowledge‚Äîlike technology‚Äîis usually necessary but rarely sufficient to engender changeTechnologychange). As we emphasize further in the next section on socio-technical bundlesBundle/bundling, institutional innovationTechnologyinnovation in civic engagementEngagement seems especially important now: innovations in engagementEngagement for AVC actors, both upstream and downstream; for policy development; and for public support (particularly through farm subsidySubsidies reform). We urgently need both technological and institutional advances that counter concentrated commercial and political power, in order to ensure authentically beneficial and inclusive innovations.

Innovations in upstream AVC actor engagementEngagement grow increasingly feasible in a rapidly digitizing and globalizing world. As discussed above, digital innovations are increasingly empowering farmers and food producers to innovate within their own circumstances‚Äîto adapt to challenges, adopt new opportunities, and/or harness the wisdom of crowds. Digital technologies increasingly enable connectivityDigital technologiesconnectivity that can facilitate greater inclusionEquity in agri-food innovationTechnologyinnovation and in shared governance, so as to accelerate and broaden impacts. Robust engagementEngagement is limited largely by connectivityDigital technologiesconnectivity, which reinforces the need for universal ruralRural broadband.

WE URGENTLY NEED BOTH TECHNOLOGICAL AND INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCES THAT COUNTER CONCENTRATED COMMERCIAL AND POLITICAL POWER, IN ORDER TO ENSURE AUTHENTICALLY BENEFICIAL AND INCLUSIVE INNOVATIONS.Just as innovations are needed to network upstream producers (i.e., farmers, fishers, herders, etc.) more effectively, so, too, is broader citizen engagementEngagement in AVC governance, a pressing issue. In some senses the world is awash with data, yet the data we need to make informed decisions is often difficult to find. This frequently occurs because data are proprietary, because there is no regulated requirement for data transparency, or because data curation services are proprietary or absent. Artificial intelligenceDigital technologiesmachine learning has made significant advances in collating, curating, and identifying associative relationships between different data streams but remains an imperfect science. Given advances in sensorDigital technologiessensors and distributed ledger (e.g., blockchain) technologies to verify key details of production, transformation, and distribution processes and to store those data in nonmanipulable forms, it is increasingly feasible for citizens to access‚Äîshould they so want‚Äîdetailed data on how the food they consume is produced, transported, and processedProcessing, as well as evidence of its safety, the contractual terms of its production and sale, etc. Social media is also driving greater transparency by shining a spotlight on issues of consumer concern (e.g., unfair laborLabor practices, unsustainable or unsafe production processes, etc.). Individual-level accessibility to such data, bringing down the energy and financialFinance costs of its production, are high priorities in order to enhance civic engagementEngagementin AFSAgri-food systems (AFS) governance.

Policy is often set and managed by governmentGovernment(s) departments‚Äîministries or public agencies that are highly silo-ed, with little public input, and based on a sectoral or segmented view of the world, one that may not accord with how real-world AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS) function. For example, in the UK, there are 16 departments or agencies involved in the regulation of the AFSAgri-food systems (AFS) and its relationship to agriculture, tradeFoodtrade, health, food safetyFoodsafety, and the wider economy. Therefore, insufficient efforts are typically made for policy development within a ministerial silo to be assessed holistically.

Innovations in this space include attempting to harvest ‚Äúthe wisdom of the crowd‚Äù through citizen assemblies, which take their form by bringing groups of citizens together to discuss issues to aid the navigation of complex policy space, and for more deliberative attempts to develop cross-governmentGovernment(s) policy solutions. One nice example is the UK‚Äôs National Food Strategy, which aims for a holistic approach to AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS), seeking system-positive outcomes, rather than outcomes that simply improve farm profitability, reduce food pricesFoodprice(s), tackle food wasteFoodwaste, or attempt to carry out some other narrow goal.

A key area for perhaps riskier and more transformative policy framing would be the use of alternative metrics of national good, beyond national incomeIncome. The level and/or rate of growth of GDP or national incomeIncome‚Äîtypically in inflation-adjusted, per capita terms‚Äîare too often regarded as the principal socioeconomic performance index. The deficienciesMicronutrientsdeficiencies of GDP and incomeIncome measures are very well known: they fail to internalize damages to nature or climate; they do not value essential nonmonetized activities (e.g., caregiving) but do value monetized destructive activities (e.g., weapons manufacture and sales); and beyond a low-level production and consumption, measures correlate weakly, if at all, with happiness and life satisfaction measures (Stiglitz et al. 2010). At a societal level, which depends on living on a finite planet, incentivizing consumption growth also drives unsustainability, which increasingly‚Äîsuch as through climate anxiety‚Äîis undermining well-being. Innovative ways to measure societal well-being in a more nuanced way than GDP have been developed (e.g., the OECD‚Äôs Better Life Index [OECD 2018]), and a few countries have begun to use these measures in place of GDP and national incomeIncome. Improved measures shift discourse in a system-positive direction. These would incentivize a very different innovation environment, as the contribution of diets to planetary health and well-being would require that they not be considered ‚ÄúexternalitiesSpillovers‚Äù to the AFSAgri-food systems (AFS).

Citizen assemblies might also inform the navigation of complex systems, where trade-offs are rife, and lead to greater clarity as to what positive systemic outcomes citizens really want, rather than relying on simple, unnuanced, and inaccurate proxies like ‚Äúconsumers want cheap food.‚Äù Lack of clarity presently facilitates special-interest-group capture of vast public agri-food sector subsidiesSubsidies, mostly in forms that distort markets and in a manner that aggravates pre-existing incomeIncome and wealth inequalityInequality because the wealthiest farmers‚Äîindeed, often just landowners who do not farm‚Äîreceive the biggest payments (OECD 2020). It is hard to believe that present subsidySubsidiesprograms reflect citizen desires as opposed to raw interest group pressures. With greater clarity around desired systemic outcomes, public money can be more effectively targeted at them. As highlighted by Springmann (2021), changing the subsidySubsidies regime can have significant impacts on food availability, price and diets, and dietary illness (e.g. refocusing subsidiesSubsidies from calorie-dense starchy grainsCerealsto fruitFruitsand vegetablesVegetables).

sec.title: Sustainable Animal and Plant Production Systems

sec.p: Innovations in this sphere range across scales from microbiome-related advancesGeneticadvances that entail interactions with plantsDiseaseplant and animalsDiseaseanimal to genetic technologies applied to microbes, animalsDiseaseanimal, and plants to agronomic and other systems-management innovations. Many of these innovations are most effective when combined, potentially leading to synergies enabling novel syndromes of production (Vandermeer 1997; Finckh 2008; Li et al. 2020a). As outlined above, innovations in genetics, breedingGeneticbreeding, and agronomy have contributed to huge improvementsParetoin productivityProductivity over recent decades, with a range of downsides that are increasingly recognized as unsustainable.

Crop innovations: The power of conventional breeding continues to benefit from myriad innovationsTechnologyinnovation that are collectively termed molecular breeding, which encompasses a range of technologies from identifying natural gene variants (alleles) of interest and selecting for them in breedingGeneticbreeding programs, to moving genes within or across species barriers through genetic engineeringGeneticengineering, as well as gene editing to alter alleles within a genome (Jaganathan et al. 2018). CropCropsimprovementPareto strategies with implications for food and nutritionNutrition include those that increase yieldsYields, those that stabilize yieldsYields and reduce losses, and those that changeTechnologychange the nutrient content of the crops. Past yieldYields increases have resulted from hybridGenetichybrid technologies, in which the superiority of the progeny of crosses between certain inbred lines has allowed for astonishing yieldYields improvement over recent decades, most notably in maizeCereals (Reeves and Cassaday 2002). Breeding new cropCrops varieties with high nutrient-use efficiency is an effective means to reduce fertilizerFertilizer use without sacrificing cropCropsyieldsYields (Shen, Li, et al. 2013; Jiao et al. 2016). Most often, this has enabled yieldYields increases with stagnant fertilizerFertilizer use patterns, as has been true for maizeCereals/corn in the US. The idea of improving yieldsYields through improved photosynthetic efficiency (e.g., C4 riceCereals) is a long-shot bet in which substantial research resources are being investedFinance (Ermakova et al. 2020). Another high-risk idea with potentially high returns is that of putting genes into cerealsCereals to enable the crops to fix nitrogen (Box 2).

For stabilization of yieldsYields, there are many natural alleles and transgenic strategies aimed at improving abiotic and biotic stress tolerance. Ensuring that plantsDiseaseplant and animalsDiseaseanimal can withstand challenges from biological aggressors is an inherently dynamic challenge because weedsWeeds (weeding), insectsInsects, and pathogens all evolve to overcome the obstacles that they encounter. For example, cropCropsgermplasmGeneticgermplasm (including the wild relatives of cultivated crops) often carries a wealth of resistance alleles that can protect crops from diseases and insectInsectspestsPest(s) when the alleles are transferred to cultivated varieties. Unfortunately, genetic resistance often breaks down rapidly when pathogens and insectsInsects evolve to evade recognition or otherwise overcome defenses (Pilet-Nayel et al. 2017); such boom-and-bust cycles also occur with pesticidesAgrochemicals. Certain forms of resistance are harder to overcome than others, and some forms of resistance may come with tradeoffs related to yieldYields or vulnerability to other biotic stresses. For example, breeding plants that resist mycotoxinsMycotoxin(s) can often lead to low-yielding varieties, and there is an urgent need to develop varieties that are resistant to toxins based on mechanisms that do not reduce yieldsYields. Elegant strategies have been devised for engineering resistance, either with gene transferDigital technologiestransfers or editing, but the implementation of these strategies has generally been complicated by public concerns about‚Äîand resulting heavy regulation of‚Äîgenetic engineeringGeneticengineering (see Box 2). While diverse pestPest(s) management options abound, from breeding to biological control to landscape management, pesticideAgrochemicals use remains a global and generally toxic default paradigm.

Similar innovations enable crops to more efficiently use nutrientsSoilnutrients like nitrogen and to cope with soil stresses such as water deficit, saltsFortificationsalt, and other abiotic challenges. Improving tolerance to transient flooding through the introduction of a gene sourced from a riceCereals variety adapted to deep waters has been an impressive success story in riceCereals (Bailey-Serres et al. 2010; Oladosu et al. 2020). While single genes with such strong effects on stress tolerance are relatively rare, most traits can be modified by conventional breeding strategies that change the allele frequencies of multiple genes with small effects on the trait. A diversity of approaches are being used by riceCereals researchers worldwide to identify the genetic variation among domesticated riceCereals species and their wild relatives that can be exploited to breed a new generation of ‚Äúgreen super rice‚Äù varieties (Wing et al. 2018).

In addition to increasing and/or stabilizing food productionFoodproduction, innovation in genetics and breedingGeneticbreeding has contributed to improving culinary and/or nutritionalNutrition quality (or to reducing quality, when these aims are not considered). BiofortificationFortificationbiofortification aims to improve the nutritionalNutrition quality of foods by improving plants‚Äô vitaminMicronutrientsvitamins, mineralMicronutrientsminerals, and/or fatty acid profiles. This can be achieved based on genes that influence the levels of nutrients in food, such as increased levels of pro-vitamin A with transgenic golden riceGolden rice or with conventionally bred orange-fleshed sweet potatoRoots and tubers. Improved nutrient content (or increased bioavailability and/or decreased anti-nutrient content) can also be achieved by selection for these traits in conventional screening and/or breeding programs.

sec.title: Box 2: Transgenic and gene editing technologies
sec.p: Following their commercial introduction in 1996, transgenic crops (‚ÄúGMOs‚Äù) are now grown on more than 190 million hectares (ISAAA 2019). The vast majority of transgenic plants currently grown contain only a few transgenesGeneticengineering that contribute to pestPest(s) management through herbicideAgrochemicals tolerance and/or insectInsects resistance genes.
