Plants expressing toxin genes from the bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis have been widely deployed, resulting in both cropCrops-yieldYieldsimprovementsPareto and reductions in pesticidePest(s) applications (Brookes and Barfoot 2018; Pixley et al. 2019). A variety of other strategies for engineered pestPest(s) resistance have also been developed (NASEM 2016; Talakayala et al. 2020). A wide variety of technically effective transgenic methods exist for managing virus diseases, for example, some of which have attained some commercial success (Pixley et al. 2019). Papaya ringspot virus (PRSV) resistance was commercialized in Hawaii in 1998 (Gonsalves 1998). Transgenic papaya for PRSV resistance was approved for commercial cultivation in southern China in 2006 (Li et al. 2007) and has been planted there on a large scale. There are many other strategies for producing disease and insectInsects resistance through gene transferDigital technologiestransfers, which can be combined in transgene cassettes carrying multiple resistance genes (van Esse et al. 2020). For example, trials are being conducted in Uganda to assess potatoRoots and tubers lines carrying multiple resistance genes against late blight (Ghislain et al. 2019).

The traits in most widely cultivated transgenics target production-related priorities, mainly pestPest(s)and weedWeeds (weeding) management. Additional transgenic approaches have shown encouraging results for enhancing other production-related traits, such as drought tolerance (e.g., NASEM 2016; Gonz√°les et al. 2020). Traits that more directly benefit consumers include those that are nutritionNutrition-related, such as vitaminMicronutrientsvitamins, mineralMicronutrientsminerals, or fatty acid contents. The production in plants of omega-3 long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids, normally sourced from fishAquaculture oils, could reduce the pressure on oceansAquaculture to supply this important nutrient that is often limited in diets. Products from the transgenic crops, carrying genes from marineAquaculture microbes, can be consumed by livestockLivestock, fishAquaculture, or humans. A number of other genetic innovations are currently in the pipeline with a focus on nutritionalNutrition enhancement of crops and livestockLivestock (NASEM 2016; Napier and Sayanova 2020).

Extending the range of plants that can capture (‚Äúfix‚Äù) atmospheric nitrogen (N) could benefit the environment by reducing the unsustainable production and use of synthetic N fertilizersFertilizer (Charpentier and Oldroyd 2010; Galloway et al. 2013; Van Grinsven et al. 2013; Ladha et al. 2020). Natural substitutes, such as leguminous crops (beans, peas, and similar), can utilize N from the environment through symbiosis with root-associated bacteria that can fix N. Other types of plants, such as the major cerealsCereals, cannot form such productive relationships. Increased use of N-fixing crops would reduce energy and GHGClimategreenhouse gas(es) emissions arising from fertilizerFertilizer manufacturing. It could also reduce nutrient (especially N) losses into the air and water that contribute to both pollution and climate changeClimatechange.

Engineering crops, especially staple cerealsCereals, to fix N is a long-standing aim toward which plant breeders have made significant advances in recent years, although no new variety is anywhere near ready for widespread release. Several strategies are being undertaken to enable this, such as transferringDigital technologiestransfers the genes that control the development of root nodule symbiosis from legumes to cerealsCereals; creating nodule-independent N-fixing cerealsCereals promoting their association with endophytes that fix N; gene editing of associative N-fixing bacteria; and directly introducing nitrogenase into the plant (Mus et al. 2016; Vicente and Dean 2017; Rosenblueth et al. 2018; Van Deynze et al. 2018; Bloch et al. 2020). The tradeoff is that N fixation is metabolically expensive for legumes because they ‚Äúfeed‚Äù their symbionts carbonClimatecarbon in return for the N fixed, so N-fixation would likely constrain yieldYields potential in cerealCereals crops. If the resulting yieldYields reductions compel expansion of the agricultural frontier, resulting in the conversion of forest to croplands, the net environmental impact of N-fixing cerealsCereals could be adverse. It therefore remains to be seen whether, and when, cerealCerealsyieldsYields and associated environmental impacts could be enhanced by incorporating N-fixing capability in the absence of applied N.

Despite the commercial success of a few categories of transgenic plants, the approach remains controversial (Chv√°talov√° 2019). As a consequence of this and the expense associated with clearing regulatory hurdles (US$7‚Äì35M out of a typical product development cost of US$136M; Phillips McDougall 2011), the transgenic crops in commercial cultivation use only a very small proportion of the genetic variation that could be accessed through this approach.

The more recent emergence of genome editing technologies (i.e., CRISPR/Cas), has made it possible to precisely alter gene sequences native to an organism. This is being widely applied to plantDiseaseplant and animalDiseaseanimal species, as a powerful tool for genetics and breedingGeneticbreeding that may obviate some transgenic approaches (van Eck 2020; Mao et al. 2019). This technology can contribute to cropCrops diversification by allowing rapid improvementPareto of key agronomic traits in hitherto neglected crops, as recently shown by leveraging insights from tomatoes to improve plant architecture and fruitFruits size in groundcherry (Lemmon et al. 2018). The regulatory environment for the utilization of this technology in agriculture‚Äîincluding the ethics of gene regulation‚Äîwill largely determine the extent to which this technology contributes to cropCrops diversification, protection, adaptation to climate-related stresses, and nutritionalNutrition quality (Zaidi et al. 2019; Smyth 2020). There seems no impending shortageWatershortages of genetic engineeringGeneticengineering applications to effectively tackle disease resistance, abiotic stress tolerance, and desirable consumer attributes; the constraints to development, diffusion and equitable impacts largely stem from social and institutional forces (Pixley et al. 2019).

To date, the focus of genetics, breedingGeneticbreeding, and seed systems has been on the deployment of high-yielding starchy staples, with some shift of focus to more diverse foods in recent years. Even within the starchy staples, there has been an extreme emphasis on a few crops, which can make for vulnerability to climate events, pestsPest(s), diseases, and other stressorsDisasters. Further investment in research beyond the major cerealsCerealscould contribute to diversified cropping systems that are better adapted to a range of environments (DeFries 2018; Mason-D‚ÄôCroz et al. 2019). Focusing more research and innovation on a much larger range of plant and animalDiseaseanimal species could support the strategic diversification of food productionFoodproduction and consumption, and help address the reduction in agrobiodiversity that has come with the focus on a narrow range of species. For example, more research on trees that produce fruitsFruits and nuts, as well as diverse vegetablesVegetables and other more nutritious and sustainable food sources, could contribute to more resilient production systems and better diets.

Creating adapted and stress-tolerant germplasmGeneticgermplasm is one set of challenges; ensuring that farmers have the germplasm they need is another. Seed value chainsValue chains remain severly underdeveloped in many low-incomeIncome countries (Ariga et al. 2019; Barriga and Fiala 2020). Facilitating the emergence of viable, reliable seed value chainsValue chains is an essential first step in promoting adaptive genetic improvementPareto research and farmer uptake of those improvements. Innovation in varietal evaluation and seed systems includes old and new strategies for working with large numbers of farmers to test varieties in diverse contexts (e.g., B√§nziger and Cooper 2001; Van Etten et al. 2019). Plant breeding is, in any case, an important but relatively small component of the socio-technical strategies needed to build the climate resilienceResilienceand sustainabilitySustainability of food systemsFoodsystems. For farmers to implement more sustainable production practices, the innovationsTechnologyinnovation must be developed; farmers must be aware of them and have the knowledge, skills, and technologies needed to implement them; and producers must actually changeTechnologychange their behavior. Experiences in the commercial, public health, and agriculture sectors illustrate that interpersonal contact can be essential in driving large-scale behavior changeTechnologychange (Gawande 2013). Large-scale agronomic studies are being conducted in China based on the ‚ÄúScience and Technology BackyardScience and Technology Backyard (STB)‚Äù (STB) system that links smallholder farmers with extensionExtension and research through a village-level innovation platform (Box 3), and elsewhere using farmer research networks and related approaches (Nelson et al. 2019; Van Etten et al. 2019). These methods show tremendous promise for drawing together the wisdom of (small farmer) crowds with the knowledge of cutting-edge scientific researchers to accelerate discovery, adaptation, and diffusion.

sec.title: Box 3: Science and technology backyards‚Äîlinking farmers, extension, agribusiness, and science at scale8
sec.p: In China, tens of millions of small-scale farmers have implemented resource-conserving and yieldYields-enhancing farming techniques through the STBScience and Technology Backyard (STB)initiative. The STBScience and Technology Backyard (STB) approach also gives researchers large datasets in near-real time to establish what works for whom through the participatory research and extensionExtensionbuilt into the approach. STBScience and Technology Backyard (STB) began with the observation that established training methods were not leading to substantial smallholder adoption of innovative cultivation methods; few farmers changedTechnologychange their practices even if they knew of the technologies. This recognition inspired China Agricultural University (CAU) researchers to strengthen their engagementEngagement with farmers. Recognizing the key role of trustTrust, and understanding the importance of two-way information flow to support agroecologicalAgroecology/icalintensificationIntensification, CAU scientists began a participatory research and training effort in Quzhou in 2009.

The researchers moved their research programs from the experimental station to the village so they could work and communicate directly with farmers, to share in their successes and failures. They rented a backyard in the village, and lived, worked, and studied in the yard. Professors and postgraduate students conducted intensive farmer participatory trainings. Gradually, farmers were attracted to the backyards, which became science and technology dissemination focal points in local communities. Trained farmers adopted high-yieldYields and high-efficiency technologies (e.g., formulated fertilizerFertilizer, sowing technology, and efficient water and fertilizerFertilizer use techniques) at much higher rates than did untrained farmers (Shen, Cui, et al. 2013; Jiao et al. 2019). The effort then scaled up dramatically.

STBScience and Technology Backyard (STB) is now a multi-actor innovation platform located in ruralRural areas that links the scientific community with smallholders, local governmentGovernment(s), and private enterprises to facilitate information exchange and technological innovationTechnologyinnovation for achieving sustainable intensificationIntensification of agriculture. The platform consists of farmer field schools, participatory on-farm research, new technology demonstrations, and farmer interest groups or clubs. Farmers get rapid and context-relevant responses to their challenges. Companies contribute their technologies and fundingFinance, quickly learning what works and what doesn‚Äôt. Local governmentsGovernment(s) provide supportive policies and extensionExtension services, earning constituent support.

In 2020, 127 STBsScience and Technology Backyard (STB) operate in 23 provinces and regions with the participation of 29 scientific research institutes and over 100 agricultural extensionExtensionstations in China. The STBScience and Technology Backyard (STB) system covers 45 major crops and has allowed significant scientific insights to be made, while facilitating transformative change that both improves yieldYields and decreases the environmental footprint of agriculture (W.F. Zhang et al. 2016; Jiao et al. 2019). In 2019, FAO partnered with CAU and AfricanAfricacountries to promote STBScience and Technology Backyard (STB) for enhancing transformation of AfricanAfrica agriculture, starting with 34 students from eight AfricanAfrica countries training at CAU before returning to their home countries to implement STBsScience and Technology Backyard (STB) (Jiao et al. 2020).

Livestock innovations: The livestockLivestock sector is often blamed for contributions to communicable and non-communicableDiseasenon-communicable disease burdens and to greenhouse gasClimategreenhouse gas(es) production. But while reduced meat consumption is recommended in industrialized food systemsFoodsystems, greater meat consumption would be beneficial to health outcomes in many low- and lower-middle incomeIncome countries (FAO 2020). Tens of millions of resource-limited households derive their livelihoodsIncomefrom livestockLivestock and improving productivityProductivity in the sector can contribute to improving nutritionNutrition and pro-poor development in general (ILRI, 2019). Many actions can boost productivityProductivity including improved grazing, better disease management, and closer integration with other on-farm enterprises such as cropCrops production. Two areas of innovation are highlighted below: improved livestockLivestock breeding and feeds.

Sophisticated livestockLivestockbreedingGeneticbreeding methods have been applied to improve livestockLivestockproductivityProductivity. AdvancedGeneticadvances genetic and genomicGeneticgenomic selection methods have the potential to contribute to heat tolerance and to methane mitigation (Pryce and Haile-Mariam 2020; more on the latter issue below). LivestockLivestockbreedingGeneticbreeding efforts that focus on other production traits tend to reduce heat tolerance, which is problematic as temperatures rise with climate changeClimatechange. This trend requires attention to breeding for heat tolerance. An example is the ‚Äúslick hair‚Äù trait, which increases thermotolerance and productivityProductivity in Holstein cows (Ortiz-Col√≥n et al. 2018). While prospects exist for accelerating traditional breeding processes for desired animalDiseaseanimal traits (Strand√©n et al. 2019; Barbato et al. 2020), an integrated approach will require both technical and social adaptations (Menchaca et al. 2020). Many indigenous livestockLivestock breeds and populations remain uncharacterized, particularly in AfricaAfrica, and much is unknown about their cross-breeding potential. Increasing the attention focused on a wider diversity of locally adapted species, including small stock such as guinea pigs, sheep and goats, may increase production in niches important to the food securityFoodsecurity of vulnerable populations.

Innovations in feed value chainsValue chainscan address a range of AFSAgri-food systems (AFS)dysfunctions. Examples include feed-based strategies for reducing methanogenesis in ruminantLivestock digestive systems to reduce greenhouse gasClimategreenhouse gas(es) production in the livestockLivestock sector; reducing the depletion of fisheries stemming from the use of fish-based fishAquaculture food; and improving the levels of omega-3 in animalDiseaseanimal and human diets. Algal-derived feed supplements can be used to substantially reduce enteric methanogenesis in ruminantsLivestock (McCauley et al. 2020). Furthermore, synergies have been observed between the effects of algal biomass on methane production and livestockLivestockproductivityProductivity.

Another innovation is the use of insectsInsects as feed. InsectsInsects are often rich in proteinMacronutrientsprotein(s) and some vitaminsMicronutrientsvitamins and mineralsMicronutrientsminerals. In the EU, black soldier fly (BSF), yellow mealworm and the common housefly have already been identified for potential use in feed products (Henchion et al. 2017). Use of some insectInsects-derived proteinMacronutrientsprotein(s) may reduce GHGClimategreenhouse gas(es) emissions, though strong evidence on this impact remains scant (Parodi et al. 2018). InsectInsects-based feeds are currently advanced mainly for their nutritionalNutrition, environmental, technological and socio-economic impacts.

Consumption of fishAquaculture and shellfish is recommended for personal and planetary health (Willet et al. 2019). A variety of innovations are improving the prospects for sustainable production of these foods. As world fisheries decline with increased anthropogenic and climate stress on the world‚Äôs oceansAquaculture, aquacultureAquaculture has become an increasingly important source of fishAquaculture and shellfish, especially in the Global South. Production from low- and middle-incomeIncome countries in South Asia, Southeast Asia, and Latin AmericaLatin America and Caribbean is increasingly responsible for the growth of global aquacultureAquaculture and shows considerable future promise (De Silva 2012; Gentry et al. 2017). Well-designed aquacultureAquaculture systems can deliver nutrient-rich foods with low environmental impact (Shepon et al. 2020).

Much of the ocean‚ÄôsAquaculturefishAquaculture catch is used to feed farmed salmonids (salmon and trout) and shrimp. Shifting away from the inclusionEquityof fishAquaculture meal in aquafeed could enable aquacultureAquaculturefarmsFarms to produce high-value products like salmon and shrimp without depleting the ocean‚ÄôsAquaculture fisheries or expanding current, less sustainable feed-cropping systems such as soy and canola (Fry et al. 2016). Options to reduce the environmental footprint of fish feed include insectsInsects, such as BSF and algae, both of which can be grown using side products (i.e., potential wastes; see Box 4). Likewise, single cell proteins (SCPs) produced via fermentationFermentation are also ideal fishAquaculture meal substitutes, and some use methane as feedstock, making them even more sustainable. Another option is camelina, an oilseed cropCrops that can be used as an animalDiseaseanimal feed to enhance omega-3 levels (Berti et al. 2016). In addition, it is well adapted to genetic manipulation and so can also be used to produce very high-value lipids (Yuan and Li 2020).

The genetic diversity of farmed fishAquaculture is currently low, and pestsPest(s) and diseases may be poorly controlled in ways that are harmful to the environment and human health (e.g., Cabello et al. 2013). The diversification of aquatic species used in aquacultureAquaculture could reduce pestPest(s) and disease pressure and provide a wider range of options for cultivation in different environments. New aquacultureAquaculture production models are emerging to tackle environmental issues such as eutrophication and mangrove loss, including landLand-based recirculating aquaculture systems (RAS), inland coastal flow-through systems for salmon and indoor farms for shrimp, and oceanAquaculture-based closed containment systems. RAS is an especially promising technology, offering the potential to grow seafood entirely indoors with minimal environmental impacts. In these systems water is continuously reused, and fishAquaculture waste, uneaten feed, nitrates, and microorganisms are filtered out. Current species approaching commercialization potential include salmon, trout, tilapia, kingfish, barramundi, and shrimp.

Agroecological innovations: The varied challenges created by modern agriculture can be addressed, at least to some extent, by a shift from reliance on hydrocarbonsClimatefossil fuel(s)-based inputs to the application of approaches that are based on agroecologicalAgroecology/ical principles such as efficiency, synergy, and circular economyCircular economy (Barrios et al. 2020). Similar concerns and approaches are described in literatures associated with the terms ‚Äúregenerative agriculture‚Äù and ‚ÄúagroecologyAgroecology/ical.‚Äù The field of agroecology (AE) entails ‚Äúthe study of the interactions between plantsDiseaseplant, animalsDiseaseanimal, humans and the environment within agricultural systems‚Äù (Dalgaard et al. 2003). The term AE is also used to refer to the science, practice and movement related to the ecological and social processes that underlie and influence farmingFarmsand AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS) (Wezel and Soldat 2009). Holistic approaches to AE consider both technical and social levels through interconnected innovations that can work together to transform food systemsFoodsystems towards greater sustainabilitySustainability (HLPE 2019).¬†The concept of agroecologicalAgroecology/ical transition has been highlighted in a number of recent reports and case studies (IPES-Food 2018; NatureScot 2020).

Gliessman (2016) outlined a series of stages that can support a transition to ecologically based agriculture. The first stage is raising efficiency. Increasing input use efficiency is a major focus of ‚Äúsustainable intensification‚Äù (e.g., Godfray et al. 2015). Important improvementsPareto in nutrient-use efficiency are being achieved by precise placement of designed nutrientsSoilnutrients in the root zone, with the quantities, composition, and timing of application guided by models (Shen, Li, et al. 2013; Wang and Shen 2019). This approach can support increased yieldsYields via root-soil-microbial interactions (Wang and Shen 2019; Wang et al. 2020). Strategic nutrientSoilnutrients application has also been coupled with intercropping to improve yieldsYields and nutrientSoilnutrients use efficiency (Li et al. 2007). A range of integrated soil fertility management (ISFM) practices similarly couple use of external inputs as essential complements to more effective use of organicOrganic materials from within the system (Place et al. 2003; Vanlauwe et al. 2010, 2015).

The second level of agroecologicalAgroecology/ical transition involves substituting natural processes for excessive use of chemicalFertilizerchemical inputs. This includes the integration of legumes into cerealCereals-based systems to bring in nitrogen, or cropCrops-livestockLivestock integration as another alternative source of cropCrops nutrients. While modern agriculture has relied on toxic chemicals to manage pestsPest(s) (i.e., insectsInsects, weedsWeeds (weeding), and pathogens), ecologically friendly management options have been, and are being, devised especially to combat emergent pesticideAgrochemicals resistance as insectsInsects and pathogens evolve in response to chemical controls. ‚ÄúBiological control‚Äù can involve the use of native natural enemies, encouraged through landscape management, as well as introduced predators of pestPest(s) species and microbial antagonists of pestsPest(s). Spectacular outcomes have been achieved towards managing the cassavaRoots and tubers mealy bug (Herren and Neuenschwander 1991) and the pearl millet head miner (Ba et al. 2014), for example, through the introduction of parasitoid insectsInsects that prey on the pests, and there are many new possibilities for biological control (van Lenteren et al. 2018). Box 4 focuses on regulatory approaches that could break the current pesticidesPest(s) lock-in.

INCREASING DIVERSITY CAN PROVIDE A RANGE OF BENEFITS THAT COLLECTIVELY IMPROVE SYSTEM RESILIENCE.The third level of agroecologicalAgroecology/ical transition entails redesigning production systems to avoid problems and drawing upon new agroecologicalAgroecology/ical principles and processes (Krebs and Bach 2018; Pretty et al. 2018; Barrios et al. 2020; Wezel et al. 2020). This may entail new crops, as well as the integration of crops, trees, and livestockLivestock, and nutrient flows between ruralRuraland urbanUrban areas. Increasing diversity can provide a range of benefits that collectively improve system resilienceResilience. For example, a long-term study of diversification via cropCrops rotation showed that maizeCerealsyieldsYields were higher with more diverse rotations, even under drought conditions (Bowles et al. 2020). Although cropCrops diversification is hardly a novel idea, shifting from monocultures and other low-diversity systems towards greater agrobiodiversity may involve innovation in breeding, agronomy (potentially including engineering), and markets (IPES-Food 2016). In a variety of contexts, redesign of integrated cropCrops-livestockLivestock systems can offer environmental and economic benefits. For example, Bonaudo et al. (2014) cite examples of successful application of agroecologicalAgroecology/ical principles towards improving system performance through cropCrops-livestockLivestock integration in Brazil (reducing deforestationDeforestation in the Amazon) and in France.

System redesign will entail diversifying production systems in time and space, considering the integration of crops, livestockLivestock, and trees‚Äîas well as external inputs‚Äîon farmsFarms and across landscapes. Diversity at these scales has implications for nutrient cycling, natural pest regulation, riskDisasters management, and, in some contexts, the diversity of consumption. Modern agriculture has too often reduced diversity; reversing this trend will require new approaches to landscape management, taking into account the interests of multiple stakeholders and the ecosystems services they require (Moraine et al. 2014; Martin et al. 2016). At the same time, we must guard against overcelebration of diversity as an end unto itself lest we riskDisasters locking in a low productivityProductivity status quo among smallholder producers who need external inputs, and perhaps greater partial specialization in order to escape povertyPoverty. The point is the need to tap the best insights of both the AE and sustainable intensificationIntensification approaches and to customize solutions to specific contexts rather than paint with too broad a brush.

PlantDiseaseplant and animalDiseaseanimalbreedingGeneticbreeding can be regarded as combinatorial genetics; breeders use recombination and selection to put together not only the best alleles but also the sets of alleles that harmonize best with each other. Similarly, combinatorial agronomy has the potential to more fully exploit the interactions of genotypes with environments, as well as the interactions of multiple cropCrops varieties and species in diversified systems. Plant varieties and species can synergize based on complementarity of resource use, as well as less obvious biochemical interactions (D.S. Zhang et al. 2016; Wen et al. 2019; Zhang et al. 2020). In addition, the performance of plantsDiseaseplant and animalsDiseaseanimal can be influenced by the microbes associated with them. For example, certain root-associated microbes can enhance nitrogen fixation in legumes, and others can benefit wider ranges of plant taxa. Growth-promoting Rhizobacteria, for example, can greatly enhance the performance of potatoesRoots and tubers grown under biotic and abiotic stresses (Grossi et al. 2020). The effective design and implementation of biodiverse landscapes is a combinatorial challenge that, unlike plant breeding, cannot easily be conducted by the private sector alone. Large-scale public engagementEngagementin innovative-farmingFarms system design can be facilitated by digital technologies and collaborations such as the Science and Technology BackyardScience and Technology Backyard (STB) (W.F. Zhang et al. 2016; Box 3) and the farmer research network approach (Nelson et al. 2019).

Diversified crops and systems, together with markets that support people‚Äôs access to diverse foods, provide a wide range of options for improving dietary nutrient intake. There is a complex relationship between the diversity of production and the diversity of diets, but there seems to be a strong positive relationship between agricultural biodiversityBiodiversity and dietary diversity in smallholder systems (Sibhatu et al. 2015; Jones 2017a, b; Sibhatu and Qaim 2018; Tobin et al. 2019). Diversity can offer a variety of important ecosystem services, from reducing epidemic potential (King and Lively 2012) to enabling different species to tap soil, water, and light resources in complementary ways that improve yieldsYields (Li et al. 2020b; IPBES 2019). Plants can also be biofortified based on improving fertilizerFertilizer use, either in the field or in controlled-environmental contexts; this does not require genetic modificationGeneticengineering (Pannico et al. 2019). Levels 4 and 5 of Gliessman‚Äôs framework for agroecologicalAgroecology/ical transitions entails reestablishing connections among those who produce and consume food, and building a new global food systemFoodsystems based on greater equityEquity and justice (Gliessman 2016). Much of this report focuses on the mechanisms that could deliver on the HERS objectives that are shared by those in the agroecologyAgroecology/ical movement and by others who may have different foci and couch their arguments in different language.

sec.title: Box 4: Regulatory nudges towards integrated pest management
sec.p: A substantial proportion of crops are lost to pestsPest(s), which are broadly defined as including the weedsWeeds (weeding), microbes, and insectsInsects that reduce yieldsYields (Oerke 2006). Despite many well-known downsides and alternatives (S√°nchez-Bayo and Wyckhuys 2019), pesticidesAgrochemicals remain the global standard approach to managing pests. The effectiveness of the pesticidePest(s) solution is showing signs of wear. Over the past several decades there has been rapid increase in the evolution of biological resistance to cropCrops protection compounds (Gould et al. 2018), and concern is growing over the environmental and health impacts of pesticidesPest(s). There are a wide variety of integrated pest managementPest(s) (IPM) alternatives, though some IPM methods may be more complex to operationalize than spraying pesticidesAgrochemicals. Regulatory pressure is needed to enable a general shift from synthetic pesticidesAgrochemicals to agroecologically-based IPM approaches.

Regulatory frameworks for the cropCrops protection industry currently vary greatly, with the strongest regulation in EuropeEurope and the weakest in many LMICs. Most current regulations in the US focus only on the active ingredient, while a growing body of research has shown that other components of product formulation can be as toxic as active ingredients (Benachour and S√©ralini 2009). Because agricultural intensificationIntensification in LMICs has the potential to increase the use of pesticidesAgrochemicals, regulatory environments need to be strengthened in these areas to ensure the safety of workers, consumers, and the environment. Farmers in AfricaAfrica are increasingly dependent on pesticideAgrochemicals use, with associated human health costs (e.g., Sheahan et al. 2017).

Regulations should require that products be able to be used safely. In low-resource contexts, farmers may lack access to personal protective equipment (PPE) necessary to manage chemicals safely, or existing PPE may be inappropriate for use in local environments‚Äîsuch as heat-trapping slickers used in hot, tropical environments where temperature increases are known to have physiological effects on workers (Masuda et al. 2020). Also, many potential users may not be literate in the languages in which safety guidance is provided. Some cropCrops protection companies have committed to the improvementPareto of training for farmers, but requirements should be introduced such that registration of a product in a market segment is not allowed unless it has been clearly demonstrated that most farmers can use it safely.

Many agroecologicalAgroecology/ical principles and practices can be used to manage pestsPest(s) without the use of synthetic pesticidesAgrochemicals or in a manner that can at least sharply reduce pesticideAgrochemicals use. The use of host plant resistance is already widespread, though seed companies that benefit from pesticideAgrochemicals sales tend to focus on improving yieldYields potential rather than resistance in their breeding programs. The use of biodiversityBiodiversity (greater diversity of cropCrops species and varieties, strategically deployed in time and space) can reduce pestPest(s) pressure and epidemic potential (McDonald 2014), while potentially contributing to system resilienceResilience and dietary diversity. Botanical pesticidesAgrochemicals (e.g., chemicals derived from plants‚Äîoften local weedy species) have proven to be useful in pestPest(s) management even in very low-resource environments, often reducing pestPest(s) populations without harming the pests‚Äô natural enemies (Stevenson et al. 2020; Sola et al. 2014). Biological control agents, including microbial pesticidesAgrochemicals, can be very specific and effective (van Lenteren et al. 2018; Lednev et al. 2020).

The cropCrops protection industry‚Äôs current profit model is based on the volume of product sold. A shift in the business model to provide a service‚ÄîpestPest(s) management‚Äîrather than a product could push the industry to develop new mechanisms for monitoring and managing pestsPest(s). In such a model, chemicalFertilizerchemical inputs would be a cost to the service, rather than the primary source of revenue. Promising IPM approaches would likely be amplified because of their potential lower cost per acre. There would also be incentives to target that limited chemical use to specific locations in a field and at specific times to minimize the development of resistance. The industry could license digital tools that identify, track, and provide targeted recommendations for sub-field pestPest(s) management approaches.

Soil health innovations: Soil healthSoilhealthposes a fundamental challenge to agriculture in all AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS). The application of mineralMicronutrientsmineralsfertilizersFertilizer can temporarily obviate productivityProductivity constraints posed by specific nutrient deficienciesMicronutrientsdeficiencies (especially N) and can, but does not always, support the maintenance of soil organic matterSoilorganic matter (SOM), which is fundamental to soil healthSoilhealth. The organicOrganic component of soil is especially critical to its structure, ability to cycle nutrientsSoilnutrients, resistance to erosion, regulation of hydrological processes, facilitating recharge, and water holding capacity. A rule of thumb holds that for every 1 percent organicOrganic matter in soil per hectare, 100,000 liters of water can be held by the soil. SOM depletion is an especially severe threat to much of AfricaAfrica and parts of South AmericaSouth America, where soils are ancient and weathered and SOM has been depleted to the point that it cannot support cropCrops growth. Strategies to boost SOM must be adapted to local soil conditions and management options, sometimes requiring increased external inputs of inorganicFertilizerchemical nutrient amendments and in other cases reduced application rates (Amelung et al. 2020).

Challenges related to soil, water, and climate are interrelated, so their solutions need to be considered and approached in an integrated way. SOM is one of the earth‚Äôs main carbonClimatecarbon pools. It can either sequester or release carbonClimatecarbon, and thus has a key role in the global dynamics of GHGsClimategreenhouse gas(es). The French governmentGovernment(s) has announced the aspirational ‚Äú4p1000‚Äù initiative, on the premise that climate changeClimatechange could be halted if carbonClimatecarbon were returned to soils at an annual rate of 0.4 percent. Climate changeClimatechange is working against us. The increasing temperatures associated with global warming make organicOrganic matter less stable, and violent rain events contribute to soil erosion and loss of organicOrganicmatter. LandLand management approaches that build and maintain soil carbonClimatecarbon can both reduce GHGClimategreenhouse gas(es) emissions and sustainably improve food and feed productionFoodproduction. These approaches include landscape management to reduce erosion, including agroforestry; and the use of cover crops, especially leguminous species that fix nitrogen and access poorly soluble forms of phosphorus by carboxylate exudation from roots (Lyu et al. 2016; Griscom et al. 2017; Wen et al. 2019). A challenge, however, is that more marginal lands and soils‚Äîwhere a disproportionate share of the ruralRural poor reside‚Äîcannot sequester much carbonClimatecarbon per unit area. Investments to build soil carbonClimatecarbon can thereby inadvertently exacerbate economic inequalityInequality without companion interventions to help those in marginal areas.

An especially promising option is increased use of carbonClimatecarbon and other nutrients recovered from organicOrganic waste, including food wasteFoodwaste, industrialFortificationindustrial waste (e.g., coffee cherry, sugarcane bagasse, sawdust, animalDiseaseanimal bones), as well as human and animalDiseaseanimal waste (urine and feces). The volumes involved, and the negative health and societal effects of these waste streams, are enormous, as are the potential benefits of recycling and reuse (Berendes et al. 2018; Mihelcic et al. 2011). Many sources of organicOrganic matter currently lead to GHGClimategreenhouse gas(es) emissions and air and water pollutionWaterpollution (e.g., nutrient loading of aquatic environments causes toxic algal blooms). Human, animalDiseaseanimal, and other organicFertilizerorganic wastes have historically been used as fertilizersFertilizer, but these practices have eroded for a variety of good reasons for which there are now technical solutions.

The recovery of nutrients and organicOrganicmatter from waste streams into agriculture could provide a wide array of benefits‚Äîincluding improved sanitation, reduced pollution, reduced GHGClimategreenhouse gas(es) burden from agriculture, improved climate resiliency, improved cropCrops production, and improved healthSoilhealth of soils and people‚Äîcontributing to achievement of most SDGsSustainable Development Goals (SDGs) (Orner and Mihelcic 2018). Sewage sludge has fertilizerFertilizer value but also the potential to contaminate soils and foods because of industrial wastes that can enter sewage systems. A large fraction of humanity is not served by sewers in any case; 2.3 billion people lack even basic sanitation, and the excreta of 4.5 billion goes into the environment untreated (WHO and UNICEF 2017). Container-based sanitation can circumvent these problems (Russel et al. 2019). Technical developments can facilitate resource recovery into agriculture, with a diversity of options that can be adapted to different contexts (Harder et al. 2019). No single step in waste-to-value chainsValue chains is prohibitively challenging, but large-scale implementation would require considerable political will and social adjustment to overcome a range of barriers to implementation.

A key barrier is the distance between the urbanUrban locations where most waste originates and the peri-urban and ruralRural loci of most agricultural production, which often makes transport of low value-to-weight waste products prohibitively expensive. This will often require low-cost processingProcessing to increase the value density of recovered waste by products. Such processingProcessing techniques are themselves important areas in need of innovation.

A key challenge associated is that improving soil healthSoilhealth is a slow-moving process, with many soil features being non-obvious and longer-term. Innovations in soil healthSoilhealth include the development of toolkits that enable people (farmers, ranchers, and other landLand managers) to discern what is happening to soils more quickly, cheaply, and reliably. Conventional soil testing is done in laboratories, using methods that require considerable time, expense, and expertise. New methods allow more farmer-friendly assessments, as well as remote sensing of soil features (Magonziwa et al. 2020). Several teams are developing lower cost, higher spatial resolution methods to assess soil chemistrySoilchemistry(organicFertilizerorganic constituents, inorganicFertilizerchemical macro- and micronutrients, pH, etc.), biologySoilbiology (microbes and macrofauna) and physicsSoilphysics (structure, including aspects that influence water infiltration and absorption). The use of spectral methods, including those that utilize low-cost, hand-held spectrometers, as well drone-based and satellite-based ones, is rapidly bringing down the cost and speed of access to soil-related data (Angelopoulou et al. 2020). Spectral methods must be complemented by digital soil mapping that leverages site-based measures, satellite-based covariates, and artificial intelligenceDigital technologiesmachine learning methods to predict at scale soil properties (e.g., micronutrient availability) that are not especially amenable to detection by spectral methods.

DIVERSIFICATION OF PRODUCTION CAN CONTRIBUTE TO HEALTHY DIETS BY PROMOTING DIETARY DIVERSITY, ESPECIALLY AMONG SEMI-SUBSISTENCE SMALLHOLDER FARMERS.The capacity to generate reliable, affordable, farm- or field-specific soil indicators and fertilizerFertilizer recommendations remains limited, however. Errors inevitably arise in soil sampling and chemical analysis procedures within and among laboratories, and in algorithms predict soil conditions based on a few imperfectly observable indicators. The marketing of technology-based advances in soil information services currently overreaches their capacity to deliver (Schut and Giller 2020), much as has been broadly the case for index insurance products intended to provide farmers with low-cost, context-specific riskDisasters management products (Jensen and Barrett 2016).

Sustainable production-system innovations connect to several of the food-system design objectives outlined above. Perhaps agroecologicalAgroecology/icalintensification‚ÄôsIntensification chief benefits relate to environmental sustainabilitySustainability: curbing the expansion of farmed landLand at the expense of nature, as well as reducing pollution associated with the indiscriminate application of fertilizersFertilizerand pesticidesAgrochemicals. Diversification of production can contribute to healthyDiet(s)healthydiets by promoting dietary diversity, especially among semi-subsistence smallholder farmers (Sibhatu et al. 2015; Sibhatu and Qaim 2018). Improving soil healthSoilhealth can improve resiliency to drought spells, thereby improving the productivityProductivity on marginal (and other) lands (Lal 2016).

By reducing plant stress, healthySoilhealth soils can also reduce a widespread food safetyFoodsafety issue: the problem of mycotoxinMycotoxin(s)contamination. MycotoxinsMycotoxin(s) are toxic metabolites produced by a range of micro-fungi that colonize foodstuffs (most notably, maizeCereals, groundnuts, tree nuts, and spices) before and after harvest. The best known are aflatoxinMycotoxin(s)and fumonisinMycotoxin(s), but hundreds of other mycotoxinsMycotoxin(s) contaminate the world‚Äôs food systemFoodsystems. AflatoxinMycotoxin(s), the most potent naturally occurring compound known, causes liver cancer, growth stunting, and immunosuppression (Routledge et al. 2016); it contaminates a quarter of the world‚Äôs foodstuffs at levels above regulatory limits, and up to 80 percent at detectable levels (Eskola et al. 2020). There are many interventions that can be used to minimize or manage mycotoxinsMycotoxin(s) along food value chainsValue chains, but ensuring soil healthSoilhealth is fundamental, as stressed plants are most vulnerable to fungal colonization. CropCrops genotype, as well as harvest and post-harvest conditions and processes, also influence mycotoxinMycotoxin(s) accumulation and exposure. Boosting food safetyFoodsafety commonly requires multiple complementary interventions.

At least four distinct, rapidly-advancing classes of innovationTechnologyinnovation are already beginning to facilitate de-agrarianization. The costs of production in this space are dropping quickly as private investment pours into novel technologies that promise to reduce the landLandand oceanAquaculture footprint of food productionFoodproduction.

The first involves the emergence of nutrient-dense food and livestockLivestock feeds based on microalgae, insectsInsects (e.g., BSF larvae), etc., as substitutes for landLand-intensive cerealsCereals and oilseeds-based proteinsMacronutrientsprotein(s)and fishAquaculture meal. The livestockLivestock sector accounts for 40 percent of the world‚Äôs agricultural GDP and contributes to the livelihoodsIncome of 1.3 billion people (Herrero et al. 2013). FeedingFoodassistanceanimalsDiseaseanimal also accounts for a large share of agriculture‚Äôs environmental footprint. Assuming continued or growing demand for proteinMacronutrientsprotein(s) concentrate for livestockLivestock feed to meet rising demand for animal-source foods, alternative livestockLivestock feeds that utilize currently neglected resources could reduce the environmental footprint of meat and aquacultureAquaculture production, while also reducing pollution from other sources and ensuring affordable and equitable access to these nutrient-rich foods.

Several multinationals have made strategic investments (often through collaborative ventures) in this field, with prominent examples such as Nestl√© and Corbion,9 as well as Unilever and Algenuity,10 for microalgae food innovations; or Buhler and Protix11for insectInsects-based food and feed. The unit-production costs of these novel alternatives are falling fast, and they should be able to compete commercially this decade with soymeal, maizeCereals, hay, fishAquaculture meal, and other conventional feeds. Research shows that these feeds are scalable, yieldYieldsanimal-sourced foodsLivestock of similar quality and safety as those based on conventional feeds, and potentially offer added health benefits (Caporgno and Mathys 2018; Smetana et al. 2019; Altmann et al. 2020; Cottrell et al. 2020).

sec.title: Box 5: Microbial, insect, and algal biomass as circular feeds
sec.p: InsectsInsects, themselves a miniature form of livestockLivestock (Barroso et al. 2017), have many advantages in feed value chainsValue chains (van Huis 2013) for the rearing and maintenance of fishAquaculture and shellfish, chickens, pigs, and pets. For example, black solider fly larvae (BSFs) can be fed organicOrganic wastes from industrialFortificationindustrial or municipal sources, such as food scraps and excreta from humans and animalsDiseaseanimal (Gold et al. 2018), and used to produce the high-quality proteinMacronutrientsprotein(s), fatsMacronutrientsFat(s), and other nutrients that are needed for livestockLivestock and humans (Patel 2019; Smetana et al. 2019). BSFs are tolerant of certain toxins, such as pesticidesAgrochemicalsand mycotoxinsMycotoxin(s), providing a disposal alternative for contaminated foodstuffs. Among other animalDiseaseanimalproteinMacronutrientsprotein(s) sources, BSF (either as a puree or meal) has a low carbonClimatecarbon footprint and low potential for ozone depletion, acidification, and eutrophication impact (Smetana et al. 2019). The BSF market is projected to grow to more than US$2.57 billion by 2030 (Byrne 2020) and has already entered middle-incomeIncome country markets such as Indonesia.12

BSF cultivation also has the potential to contribute to human waste management, thus providing an avenue towards achieving SDG 6, which concerns ensuring access to water and sanitation. Most human excreta and other organicOrganic wastes currently go untreated into waterways, with 92 percent of wastes being untreated in low-incomeIncome countries and 80 percent untreated at a global level (Sato et al. 2013). The use of organicOrganic wastes for BSF production could improve water quality and safety while producing high-quality feed. A concern about BSF-based waste utilization relates to chemical and microbial safety. For example, the possibility of heavy metal contamination was demonstrated, as BSFs bioaccumulate heavy metals present in their diets. (BSFs have, thus, been considered for bioremediation [Bulak et al. 2018].)

Single cell proteins (SCPs) offer another high-potential source of nutritionNutritionfor inclusionEquity in feed for aquacultureAquacultureand livestockLivestock. SCPs are proteinMacronutrientsprotein(s) meals based on microbial or algal biomass, and can be produced by yeast, bacteria, microalgae, and protists. These microorganisms generate proteins after consuming sustainable feedstocks including methane, wastewater, industrialFortificationindustrial and agricultural residues, methanol, syngas, and second-generation sugars. SCP manufacturers are scalingScaling up operations globally, including commercial-scale plants in the developing world (Jones et al. 2020).13

Microalgae are another valuable, well-rounded source of biomass, proteinMacronutrientsprotein(s), oils, and mineralsMicronutrientsmineralsfor aquacultureAquaculture, livestockLivestock, and humanDiseasehumanconsumption. FishAquaculture and fish oils are valued in human diets for their high omega-3 fatty acid contents, which are derived from the microalgae on which they feed. Sourcing these high-value oils directly from microalgae could reduce offtake pressure on marineAquaculture fisheries, which are the main current source of fishAquaculture meal and fishAquaculture oil feeds.14

Lutein, a widely used carotenoid for food coloring as well as a dietary supplement, is sourced from microalgae. Lutein-rich spirulina microalgae (cyanobacteria Arthrospira) are used as a supplement for fishAquaculture and human nutritionNutrition (Shah et al. 2018). Microalgae can be farmed in marineAquaculture or closed-loop production systems to produce food and feed, while capturing nutrients that can otherwise damage aquatic resources. Contained production systems can be designed at varying scales, either with controlled lighting or in the dark with controlled carbohydrate inputs. However, due to limited technology readinessTechnologyreadiness levels and economies of scale, both types of production systems are energy intensive and require substantial capital investment in many regions (Smetana et al. 2017).

The second class of innovations rely on tissue engineeringAlternative proteinstissue engineering methods that culture cells to grow animalDiseaseanimal tissue outside the body, without the environmental, animalDiseaseanimal welfare, or financialFinance costs of raising and slaughtering live animalsDiseaseanimal. These ‚Äúclean‚Äù or ‚Äúcellular‚Äù meats have attracted considerable private investment and media attention. The commercial threat these products pose to conventional livestockLivestock producers has already prompted legislative and regulatory battles in some OECD economies over product labeling (i.e., what constitutes ‚Äúmeat‚Äù). Although these products remain expensive, unit costs are dropping fast and are predicted to fall to the level of conventional ground beef by 2026 (Tubb and Seba 2019).

The third group of landLand-saving food innovations relies on controlled environment agricultureControlled environment agriculture (CEA) (CEA)‚Äîso-called ‚Äúindoor‚Äù or ‚Äúvertical‚Äù farmingFarms‚Äîmuch of it based on aero-, aqua-, or hydro-ponic methods. CEA is growing quickly to serve urbanUrban middle- and upper-class consumers in OECD and Asian countries. Its comparative advantage lies in year-round localized supply chainsValue chains delivering consistent-quality, high-value, short-cycle horticulturalFruits products (Pinstrup-Andersen 2018; WWF 2020). Falling electricity costs and more reliable and affordable small-scale (e.g., rooftop) renewable energy generation increasingly obviates CEA‚ÄôsControlled environment agriculture (CEA) loss of free sunshine to stimulate plant photosynthesis. But especially in an environment of low borrowing costs to enable firmsFirmsto investFinancein capital-intensive CEAControlled environment agriculture (CEA) methods, and in the face of increasing water scarcity that is more easily managed in compact spaces than in large, open fields, CEAControlled environment agriculture (CEA) is becoming increasingly viable as a means of expanding the supply of leafy greens and fast-growing (i.e., not tree-based) fruitsFruits.

The fourth group of innovations uses microbes and fungi to produce novel foods through a process broadly known as ‚Äúprecision fermentation.‚Äù FermentationFermentation is a centuries-old process used to make beer, cheese, etc., in virtually every culture globally. Recent advances in synthetic biology now enable labs to design micro-organisms (e.g., bacteria, microalgae, or yeasts) that produce more complex proteinsMacronutrientsprotein(s) from inexpensive feedstocks. This is the technology behind rapidly growing commercial enterprises such as Beyond Meat, Impossible Foods, and OmniFoods. This technology is not new; Quorn has employed the versatile mycoprotein since 1985 to make meat analogues. But precision fermentationFermentation has been taking off in the past few years as advances in (especially synthetic) biology have enabled cost reductions and improved customization of target proteinsMacronutrientsprotein(s). In the first seven months of 2020 alone, these technologies attracted at least US$435 million in new investment, more than 3.5 times the capital raise by cultured/cellular meat companies globally (Shieber 2020). Precision fermentationFermentation methods can likely scale at costs below those of conventional systems for producing animalDiseaseanimal-source foods, generating a promising alternative to meet rapidly growing demand for more complex proteins without needing intermediation by livestockLivestock (Buckler and Rooney 2019; Tubb and Seba 2019).

As incomesIncome increase, rapidly growing demand will inevitably deepen further for each of these de-agrarianizedDe-agrarianize/ation methods. Rising incomeIncome, urbanization, and increased demand for shorter supply chainsValue chains, and growing consumer concerns about nutritionNutrition, food safetyFoodsafety, animalDiseaseanimal welfare, and the environmental impacts of conventional farm production methods will reinforce the momentum behind novel, landLand-saving food production methods, especially as companies and policymakers work to overcome consumers‚Äô natural skepticism about novel products (Siegrist and Hartmann 2020). The opportunity arises for technological leapfroggingTechnologyleapfroggingin AfricaAfricaand AsiaAsia, in particular, as promising technologies that were previously unaffordable (e.g. CEAControlled environment agriculture (CEA), precision fermentationFermentation) are becoming commercially viable at scale any place with reliable energy, adequate urbanUrban market size, and a literate workforce with sufficient basic scientific training. LMICs can use ruralRural lands to farm carbonClimatecarbon, solar, wind, and geothermal heat, not just crops and livestockLivestock, while simultaneously deploying novel technologies to design and deliver healthier foods‚Äîand remunerative urbanUrban and peri-urban jobs‚Äîbased on shorter supply chainsValue chains to meet growing urbanUrban food demand. In so doing, we can convert agri-food sectors from a GHGClimategreenhouse gas(es) source to a sink, shift nutritionalNutrition transitions in a healthier direction, and facilitate a structural transformation that harnesses looming demographic changes to simultaneously boost sustainabilitySustainability, resilienceResilience, inclusionEquity, and healthyDiet(s)healthy diets.

As promising as these landLand-saving methods are as a means to address sustainabilitySustainability, healthyDiet(s)healthy diets, and resilienceResilience objectives simultaneously, they riskDisasters major social disruption, especially in ruralRural areas that heavily depend on conventional farmingFarms. Major technological changeTechnologychange inevitably unleashes what Joseph Schumpeter (1942) famously termed ‚Äúcreative destruction.‚Äù Without a concerted effort to transition ruralRuraleconomies, as lower costs of de-agrarianizedDe-agrarianize/ationfood productionFoodproductionincreasingly undercut the profitability of conventional livestockLivestockand feed crop production, we run a real riskDisastersof a cascading calamity of farm bankruptcies, farmer suicides, and ruralRuralunrest.

So what alternative sources of incomeIncome exist for agricultural landowners and workers? We see at least three options. The first is renewable energy production, demand for which is growing rapidly around the world, especially as technological advances continue to drive down the costs of generating electricity from geothermal, solar, and wind sources and as off-grid alternatives have become increasingly viable. Lease royalties from energy companies and power utilities, and the non-farm value addition made feasible by reliable local power generation open up new livelihoodIncome options for agricultural communities. Indeed, there is reinforcing feedback between renewable energy production and novel, non-farm food productionFoodproduction methods because cost-reducing technological changeTechnologychange in one sector helps lower costs in the other. Relying just on unregulated energy markets and AVCsValue chains, therefore, seems a high-riskDisasters strategy for ruralRural communities.

A second option is for governmentsGovernment(s) to implement carbonClimatecarbontaxesTaxesand investFinance more in establishing viable emissions trading systems (i.e., carbonClimatecarbon markets) and the digital technologies necessary for low-cost, reliable verification of GHGClimategreenhouse gas(es) fluxes to support monetizing sequestration activities. The current global average carbonClimatecarbon price across both regulated and voluntary markets is only US$2/tCO2, far below the US$40‚Äì80/tCO2 range necessary to cost-effectively reduce emissions in line with the Paris Agreement (HLCCP 2017; World Bank 2020). GHGClimategreenhouse gas(es) sequestration is feasible in regenerative agriculture using sustainable farmingFarms practices, although concerns remain (Schlesinger and Amundson 2019). These environmental services can generate mitigation benefits to supplement agricultural earnings as farmsFarms diversify into harvesting GHGClimategreenhouse gas(es), solar, and wind, as well as commodities.

The third option is payments for ecosystem services (PES), which have grown popular worldwide, with an estimated US$40 billion or so in annual transactions (Salzman et al. 2018), with estimates for the potential revenues to the US‚Äô agriculture sector alone ranging as high as US$14 billion (Informa and IHS Markit 2018). PES have clearly demonstrated favorable impacts when well designed, although a range of design flaws continue to impede broad use and may limit sustainabilitySustainability gains (Jayachandran et al. 2017; Jack and Jayachandran 2019). Thus, PES are useful instruments, but no panacea. They appear to work most effectively in contexts involving few and large beneficiaries of the environmental services, such as hydroelectric companies or municipalities.

These alternative uses of agricultural lands create a terrific opportunity for policy innovation, in particular by repurposing farm subsidiesSubsidies. OECD (2020) estimates that across 54 countries which it tracks, transfersDigital technologiestransfers to the agricultural sector averaged US$708 billion/year for 2017‚Äì2019, of which fully US$425 billion was budgetary spending, with the rest coming through market-price support programs. Three-quarters of the amount goes to individual producers, mostly in forms that distort markets. Eliminating massive subsidiesSubsidies seems a political non-starter in most or all of the countries where they are large. But it may be politically feasible to transition from uncoupled farm payments or expensive market price supports to subsidiesSubsidies for farmer capital investments in renewable energy structures, in PES, in landLand conversion for GHGClimategreenhouse gas(es) sequestration, and in the digital technologies‚Äîand supporting market infrastructureInfrastructure‚Äînecessary to monetize those energy and environmental services. A more forward-looking approach to the use of politically explosive farm subsidiesSubsidies can safeguard ruralRural communities for the coming future when de-agrarianizedDe-agrarianize/ation production methods begin undercutting ruralRural economies heavily dependent on conventional agricultural commodity production.

Facilitating landLand conversion from agriculture will also require action regarding landLand use rules. Secure landLand tenure is essential to induce investment in GHGClimategreenhouse gas(es) mitigation in trees, soils, or cover crops, much less in installation of wind turbines or solar panel arrays. Concerted efforts will be necessary to overcome commonplace local opposition (e.g., ‚ÄúNot In My Backyard!‚Äù NIMBYism) regarding the siting of wind turbines, solar panels, protected areas for predators, etc. These are delicate processes but essential to transitioning ruralRural landscapes.

Purposeful changes are needed for AVCsValue chains that extend from the farm through to the consumer and end-of-life material considerations. We emphasize six key facets needing‚Äîand increasingly getting‚Äîattention from food and beverage companies, ingredient suppliers, global governance structures, non-governmental organizations, wholesale and retail operations, and national policy makers.

The first surrounds value chainValue chainscertificationCertification standards. Many claims about a product‚Äôs environmental, ethical, or healthful properties‚Äîits credence attributes‚Äîcannot be verified directly by purchase or consumption (Barrett 2021). This makes it difficult for firmsFirms to monetize the value of desirable product characteristics and, thus, to use market mechanisms to incentivize such innovations. In several regions, governmentGovernment(s) agencies, like the US Food and Drug Administration and the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), regulate heath claims based on scientific evidence on the label. Regarding environmental sustainabilitySustainability of products or services, a large European initiative is now evaluating a label called Product Environmental Footprint, which builds on prior prototypes and studies (e.g., Leach et al. 2016). Companies like Unilever propose to explicitly report associated GHGClimategreenhouse gas(es) emissions on the packaging of tens of thousands of products. The International Organization for Standardization (ISO) standards for carbonClimatecarbon labelling require a full life-cycle analysis and third-party verification, the cost of which poses a potential hurdle for small- and medium-sized companies and for mass labelling. A future area of innovation may focus on ways to reduce the cost of these assessments and potentially automate for large numbers of varied products. However, it also seems challenging to agree on a representative and simple sustainabilitySustainability indicator that consumers understand, that is widely adopted and recognized by different stakeholders, and that covers the various dimensions needed (Chaudhary et al. 2018; Chen et al. 2019). For example, nutritionNutrition and linked health impacts are essential, but are not considered in the Product Environmental Footprint.

The emergence of harmonized standards and associated measures, with traceable, trackable, scrapable product-level data, could ultimately supplant costly third-party certificationCertification if individual companies‚Äô and industries‚Äô compliance becomes fully transparent and independently verifiable by governmentGovernment(s) regulators and consumer groups.

In the near term, KPMsKey performance metricswithin certificationCertification schemes need to evolve to reliably capture key indicators (discussed below) that directly support the SDGsSustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and SBTs. In order to deliver broad-based change, in particular with small- and medium-sized value chainValue chainsparticipants, certificationCertification schemes require reciprocity and KPM convergence so as not to unfairly burden upstream players, especially small-holder farmers (Loconto and Dankers 2014). CertificationsCertification are to be built around principles of continuous improvementPareto rather than either achievement of a standard that is then passively maintained, or such a high entry hurdle that it dissuades parties from initiating the scheme (Blackman and Rivera 2011). KPMsKey performance metrics must be supported through nonmanipulable tracking and traceabilityTraceability technologies of the sort we discuss below.

CertificationCertification frameworks would be best linked to relevant objectives and indicators. When a certificationCertification process is established, it brings an ecosystem of frameworks that support measurement, verification, transparency, capability building, and communication (e.g., third-party certificationCertification bodies, technical panels to oversee measures, standards and technical resources developed for user networks, etc.).

Designing for an ecosystem of measures, protocols, resources, and consumer communication acknowledges the ongoing infrastructureInfrastructure and support required to drive long-term continuous improvement across KPMsKey performance metrics. Protocols and resources are the domain of value chainValue chainsparticipants, certificationCertification bodies, auditors, civil society, and, where possible, governmentGovernment(s) actors who all come together pre-competitively to build the elements of the scheme and a means of continuous improvementPareto by establishing protocols, independent and verified auditing, best-practice sharing, training, and capability building.

CertificationCertification schemes create clear expectations about standards and compliance, thereby generating credibility and consumer trustTrust at point of purchase. Such trustTrust is essential to monetize latent consumer willingness to pay for credence attributes and thereby internalize key climate, environmental, and social externalitiesSpillovers generated throughout the AVC. Standards must also be easily and reliably communicated to consumers in simple, easy-to-understand messaging and icons or logos that indicate verified performance and transparency. Avoidance of logo proliferation is important, however, so as not to sow confusion among consumers. Furthermore, while larger producers may be capable of achieving and maintaining multiple certificationsCertification, smallholders rarely can, so elimination of unique (and other high-cost) certificationCertification criteria and mutual recognition between platforms is essential to focus the value chainValue chains on clear outcomes that make a difference while meeting the needs of a diverse array of consumers and producers.

This requires more cooperation than presently occurs among AVC actors. It requires pre-competitive partnership of large-scale end users of food and ingredients with global governing bodies, relevant civil society organizations, existing certificationCertification bodies, suppliers, and implementation partners. While progressive enterprises should be encouraged to pilot innovative methods, in order to generate scalable, trustedTrust methods, such experiments must be done in the spirit of shared learning to be incorporated into the meta-system to benefit all parties. This will also require a modular approach reflecting the heterogeneityHeterogeneityof underlying AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS) and starting points.

The second key supply chainValue chains innovation space, closely related to certificationCertification, concerns consumer transparency. This has a robust foundation in food and beverage nutritionalNutrition labeling that is currently coordinated through Codex Alimentarius, a collection of internationally adopted food standardsFoodstandards and related texts jointly supervised by FAO and the World Health Organization (WHO). The Codex legacy of fact-based disclosure must be extended to key indicators that support the UN SDGs and SBTs, and HERS objectives more broadly (Box 6). The potential consumer and social benefits from food labelingFoodlabel are considerable but often limited by the imperfect information available to purchasers, along with consumer behavioral biases (Sunstein, in print).

sec.title: Box 6: Towards fact-based sustainability labelling
sec.p: In the early 1970s, consumer transparency in foods and beverages was improved with refinement of a standardized nutritionNutrition-facts table printed on pre-packaged foods. Its development was initially supported by the US Food and Drug Administration and has evolved to governance and technical oversight by Codex Alimentarius, a UN body under joint WHO and FAO direction (Codex Alimentarius 2017). Some version of the nutritionNutrition facts label is mandatory for packagedFoodpackage/ing foods in 58 countries and voluntary in another 19 (EUFIC 2016). This adoption rate, with technical rigor and coordination through a central governance body, supports global consistency for package labels. The precise regulation of labelling compliance is carried out at the country level. This system supports consumer confidence in food and beverage nutritionalNutrition disclosures, empowering consumers to make reliable inter-product assessments when making purchasing choices and enabling companies to elicit revenue from consumer valuation of improved nutritionalNutrition content.

These elements‚Äîcentral governance, technical rigor based on agreed and credible measures, local enforcement, and transparent and fact-based disclosure focused at individual consumers‚Äîset a precedent relevant to the challenge of communicating other HERS-related product attributes to consumers at the point of purchase. Lessons from the nutritionNutrition-facts label experience can inform development and consumer-directed communications of sustainabilitySustainabilitykey performance measuresKey performance metricsthat support the SDGsSustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and SBTs (Leach et al. 2016). Such labelling regimes can activate latent consumer valuation of product credence attributes, thereby internalizing spilloverSpillovers effects and generating revenues necessary to cover the costs of improving environmental, equityEquity, and health outcomes associated with specific food products. With credible measures and certified quantification, food and beverage markets can compete on a more equal footing, transcending greenwashing concerns with enhanced transparency, benefiting a range of AVC participants, and thereby advancing fruitful product and process innovations.

Transparency must also include disclosure of provenance for ingredients that, when combined with nutritionalNutrition and third-party verified credence characteristics, paves the way to consumer trustTrust and informed decision making. Here again, emergent technologies to enable nonmanipulable tracking and traceabilityTraceability become important. A number of promising initiatives are in early stages, such as the European Union‚Äôs Product Environmental Footprint pilots or Unilever‚Äôs GHGClimategreenhouse gas(es) labeling initiative, as described above. The potential to create universally recognized and respected labels, backed by reliable standards and testing, that earn and maintain consumer and regulator trustTrustopens up exciting opportunities to induce beneficial innovation by incentivizing it for AVC firms.

The third class of promising supply chainValue chains innovations are in food processingProcessing and are based on different (1) operations (structuring, conversion, stabilization, and separation), (2) processes (physical: thermal, electro-magnetic, and mechanical; and biotechnological), or (3) product property scales (nano, micro, meso, and macro scale). Especially due to emerging needs for urbanUrban food productionFoodproduction, small-scale modular factories (Mathys 2018) for processingProcessing close to production or urbanUrban environments (e.g., megacities) are receiving more attention, as improved energy and water delivery technologies and robotization reduce economies of scale. Focused process synthesis approaches (Westerberg 2004) to adapt new ingredients (e.g., plantDiseaseplant-based ingredients in place of animalDiseaseanimal-sourced ones) and desired final product attributes, (e.g., preferred organoleptic properties) are especially crucial. These process-synthesis approaches can deliver innovative product property scales, from nano to macro, not only for mimicking meat structures, from myofibrils (meat fibers) to final structured product, but also for enabling emerging single-cell and plant-based proteinAlternative proteinsplant-based protein(s)-rich products with new structures and ingredients to deliver preferred organoleptic properties such as superior taste, nutritionNutrition, and mouth feeling.

Emerging structuring/conversion processes‚Äîsuch as advanced high-moisture extrusion, 3D printingProcessing, shear cell technology, spinning, and stem cell techniques (i.e. for lab meat)‚Äîenable innovative meat substitutes or new protein-rich products based on more sustainable proteins (Dekkers et al. 2018). New ways of food stabilization/preservationProcessing based on the Multi-Hurdle Technology (MHT) (Leistner and Gorris 1995) concept deliver safe food with higher qualities, including emerging physico-chemical hurdles to reduce water activity, such as solar driers combined with moisture control that allow smallholders to preserve fruitsFruitsand vegetablesVegetables; and physical hurdles with less thermal intensity, such as ultra-short thermal processes in milli seconds; high pressure (isostatic and dynamic), pulsed electric fields; low- or high-energy electron beam; or cold atmospheric pressure plasma processingProcessing (Reineke and Mathys 2020).

WE EXPECT THAT PENALTIES AND INCENTIVES WILL BOTH BE NEEDED TO REMOVE PIGMENTS, ADDITIVES, AND POLYMERS THAT MAKE RECYCLING UNECONOMICAL CURRENTLY.High throughput separation processes can clean/sanitize contaminated commodities (e.g. mycotoxinMycotoxin(s)contaminated grainsCereals).16 Building out the capability for precision fermentationFermentation or single cell biorefineries of lipids (e.g., polyunsaturated fatty acids), precision or cellular proteinsAlternative proteinscellular protein, and carbohydrates (e.g., exopolysaccharides) with cascade-wise extraction of, first, functional and then, bulk ingredients will help to reduce AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS)‚Äô landLand and water footprint when done in ways that boost carbonClimatecarbon sequestration and biodiversityBiodiversity. Multi-processingProcessing biorefineries will emerge to integrate various process innovations, much as already exist for grainsCereals, sugar, etc.

The fourth class of promising supply chainValue chains innovations concern packaging. Ultra-processedProcessing foods, in particular, are not only associated with adverse health outcomes, they also use extensive packaging that has serious disposal impacts worldwide, ranging from toxic compounds, to hazards to wildlife, to solid waste (Seferidi et al. 2020). Besides reduction of packaging materials, the transition from single-use plastics/virgin abiotic material to 100 percent recyclable, biodegradable, or compostable materials must quickly become the norm worldwide. This will require investment and legislation that supports sufficient recycling infrastructureInfrastructure (open loop, closed loop, and chemical) to match the packaging material being used and behaviors through the life cycle to recapture molecules for reuse. We expect that penalties and incentives will both be needed to remove pigments, additives, and polymers that make recycling uneconomical currently. Beyond enablement of recycling and renewable resource utilization, there remains a significant gap in available technologies via monomers and compostable organicOrganic packaging materials that feasibly deliver required barrier properties (oxygen, water vapor, light, aroma, etc.) or the technologies may not have the right physical properties (personal communication Prof. Sel√ßuk Yildirim, ZHAW, Switzerland). Many activities in this space are running in industrial environments and are not published, hence the status quo is not quite clear. Recent developments in food-processing multinationals demonstrate the increasing focus on recyclable, biodegradable, or compostable packaging materials, for example, the 2019 establishment of the new Nestl√© Institute of Packaging Sciences.

Rapid advances in waste management represent the fifth promising supply chainValue chains innovation space. In general, the waste management hierarchy indicates an order of preference for action to reduce and manage waste.17 First comes prevention: preventing and reducing waste generation. Next comes reuse and preparation for reuse, giving the products a second life before they become waste. The next priority is recycling, consisting of any recovery operation by which waste materials are reprocessed into products, materials, or substances whether for the original or other purposes. This is followed by energy recovery, such as waste incineration that upgrades less inefficient incinerators. The lowest priority is disposal of waste, be it landfilling, incineration, pyrolysis, gasification, or other finalist solutions. This hierarchy is rapidly winning acceptance by local to national governmentsGovernment(s) and is being incorporated into standard operating practices at successful companies (Hansen et al. 2002; UNEP 2013).

Food wasteFoodwaste and lossesFoodloss occur at different points in the value chainValue chains, each requiring different innovations. Many require behavioral change more than scientific or engineering advances. For example, according to the Rockefeller Foundation Report ‚ÄúReFED: The Roadmap to Reduce US Food Waste,‚Äù major impacts for food wasteFoodwaste and lossFoodloss reduction in the US are linked to awareness, traceabilityTraceability, and transparency (ReFED 2016). Food lossFoodloss reduction strategies in low-incomeIncome regions are complex and involve, for example, awareness-raising combined with training and organization of smallholders, and improved storage and preservationProcessing capacities (e.g. for fruitsFruitsand vegetablesVegetables), distribution, and logistics (Cattaneo et al. 2021). Awareness, traceabilityTraceability, and transparency are also needed here.
