A recent global assessment of nutritionalNutrition and environmental lossesFoodloss embedded in food wasteFoodwaste could serve as a base for tracking potential intervention impacts, supporting policies or investments, and engaging various stakeholders within the value chainValue chains (Chen et al. 2020).

Some further technical-focused solutions might include (1) distribution and storage of higher quality and fresher foods, stabilized/preserved by emerging MHT concepts at ambient temperatures instead of energetic and partially challenging cold chains; (2) building out uses and upcycling of AVC by-products, for example, providing ingredients for brewers, distillers, and manufacturers; or (3) technology for digitally customizing individual serving/portion sizes in away-from-home dining.

As mentioned above, the sustainabilitySustainability issues related to fertilizerFertilizer use and soil depletion can be addressed by innovations at the nexus of sanitation, energy, and soil healthSoilhealth. A range of possibilities are being explored to deal with organicOrganic byproducts of animalDiseaseanimal agriculture, industry, and human digestion. One set of options entails anerobic digester technologies that can be introduced into both private AVCsValue chains that are generating waste products that cannot be upcycled, and into urbanUrban settings that generate an estimated 2.8 billion metric tons of organicOrganic waste annually. Outputs from an anerobic digester can support local electricity production, and the solids can be combined with aqueous ammonia to produce an organicFertilizerorganicfertilizerFertilizer for use by local farmers. The precision fermentationFermentation model would also contribute to more local production and less generated food wasteFoodwaste.

The final promising innovation space in supply chainsValue chains relates to initiatives to enhance value chainValue chainsresilienceResilienceto shocksDisasters. Some of those innovationsTechnologyinnovation are technological. For example, MHTs will support resiliency as they increase the ability to store and also reduce food wasteFoodwaste. Others are less innovations than investments to reinforce or relocate key transport infrastructureInfrastructure. Sea level rise due to global warming poses an especially grave threat because seaports are overwhelmingly located in low-lying coastal zones and delta regions.18Sea level rise will affect ports through incremental, as well as catastrophic, flooding that damages infrastructureInfrastructureand cargo.19 In 2005, Hurricane Katrina halted shipping at three Gulf ports in the US, which together handle 45 percent of the nation‚Äôs agricultural goods and resulted in a 3 percent increase in food pricesFoodprice(s) temporarily (Drabenstott and Henderson 2005). Recent studies reinforce the magnitude of sea level rises and the irreversible impacts of ice sheet loss on coastal populations and infrastructureInfrastructure (Garbe et al. 2020). Ports around the globe are under-prepared to cope with these challenges. A survey of seaports that collectively account for over 16 percent of global seaborne trade reveals that although 70 percent of the respondents have, or plan to have, emergency response measures, about 40 percent do not have, or do not plan to have, any vulnerability assessments, and 41 percent have yet to conduct any identification and evaluation of potential adaptation measures (Asariotis et al. 2018). The survey also reports that instead of soft adaptation strategies, such as changes in operations and management, respondent ports mainly chose hard engineering measures as the main strategy with an average cost of US$127.3 million.

The projected effects of sea level rise are quite spatially concentrated. Eight Asian countries‚ÄîBangladesh, China, India, Indonesia, Japan, Thailand, the Philippines, and Vietnam‚Äîare home to more than 70 percent of the world population now occupying landLand vulnerable to sea level rise (Kulp and Strauss 2019). Indonesia‚Äôs recent decision to move its capital from a swelling and sinking coastal city, Jakarta, to eastern Borneo is partly a direct response to the perils posed by sea level rise. Bangladesh and Vietnam are especially vulnerable, as roughly one-third of each country‚Äôs population will permanently fall below high tide line by 2100, even with a significant reduction in emissions. The most catastrophic cases will obviously be low-lying small island states, whose very existence may be imperiled by rising seas.

Singapore provides an illuminating example of how nations are adapting to various threats posed by AVC disruptions. Currently, Singapore produces only 10 percent of the food its population consumes. Historically, this has worked fine, as inexpensive imports reliably supplied the island nation‚Äôs food needs. Even before the COVID-19COVID-19pandemicCOVID-19 threatened imports due to commercial freight shutdowns and export bans imposed by some exporters, thus making Singapore‚Äôs low self-supply rate a vulnerability, the governmentGovernment(s) was committed to substantially increasing its self-provisioning of food so as to reduce vulnerability to short-term disruptions arising from any of a host of shocksDisasters (Zulkifli 2020). The threats posed to Singapore‚Äôs port infrastructureInfrastructure by sea level rise merely aggravate the looming problem. The nation has now made it a strategic priority to increase domestic production to satisfy 30 percent of its nutritionalNutrition needs by 2030. This is fueling rapid upscaling of investments in CEA, circular feedsCircular economycircular feeds, and other forms of de-agrarianizedDe-agrarianize/ation food and feed production, given the scarcity of landLand on the island, as well as advances in food loss and waste recovery and in food processingProcessing so as to triple domestic supply within a decade.

Important downstream innovations show particular promise in advancing the healthyDiet(s)healthy diets objective, but that may also help advance other AFSAgri-food systems (AFS) goals. We coarsely lump these into three categories: new nutritious foods, nutritious supply chainValue chains innovations, and new frontiers in human nutritionNutrition.

New technologies are emerging to produce and formulate new nutritious foods or new variations of foods to ensure that the food supplyFoodsupply is providing healthier foods while potentially, at the same time, addressing climate changeClimatechange and environmental concerns, as well as issues of equityEquityand inclusionEquity in food distribution. One such technology is 3D printingProcessing, which can make a three-dimensional object based on layer-by-layer deposition following computerDigital technologiescomputers/ing aided design (Yang et al. 2017). With 3D printingProcessing, ingredients can be mixed and processedProcessing into intricate designs and shapes, introducing new flavors and textures that cannot be currently formulated by regular cooking processes. 3D printingProcessinghas the potential to support personalized food manufacturing through home scale production. Questions, nonetheless, remain about consumer acceptance of 3D printedProcessing foods. And it is unclear whether 3D printingProcessing would promote healthier diets or reduce food lossFoodloss and wasteFoodwaste.

Genetic modificationGeneticengineering (GM) of organisms is another technology that has grown through a range of advancesGeneticadvances in genetics and genomics that enable the changeTechnologychange, removal, or addition of genes to crops and livestockLivestock that are believed beneficial for one reason or another. The earliest GM agri-food technologies promoted shelf-stabilityProcessing in tomatoes, stimulated lactation in cows, obviated the slaughter of calves in extracting rennet for cheesemaking, and especially introduced pestPest(s)and/or herbicideAgrochemicals resistance to field crops like canola, cotton, maizeCereals, and soy. These initial ventures were largely aimed at boosting or stabilizing production (Qaim 2016). Second generation GM agri-food innovations increasingly address nutritionNutritionissues‚Äîsuch as micronutrient deficienciesMicronutrientsdeficiencies‚Äîthat remain prevalent in too many LMICs (Glass and Fanzo 2017). To address micronutrient deficienciesMicronutrientsdeficiencies, staple crops such as maizeCereals, riceCereals, and wheatCereals could either use GM technology or conventional or accelerated breeding to increase the nutritionalNutrition content of vitamin AMicronutrientsvitamins, zincMicronutrientsminerals, or ironMicronutrientsminerals, for example, through an innovation known as biofortificationFortificationbiofortification (Bouis and Saltzman 2017; CAST 2020). One such example of a nutrient-rich GM cropCrops is the controversial golden riceGolden rice in which beta-carotene was built into the riceCerealsgrainCereals to produce a vitamin A‚Äîrich riceCereals product (Regis 2019; Stokstad 2019).

The alternative proteinsMacronutrientsprotein(s) discussed above open up a range of prospective nutritionNutrition innovations. Precision protein (also known as single cell protein or microbial protein) is produced by a microbe (algae, fungi, yeast, or bacteria). The microbe may, or may not, be bioengineered, and the product may be secreted from the organism or processedProcessing within the cell. Cellular proteinsAlternative proteinscellular protein (also known as cultured or tissue engineered meat) are produced as multi-cellular animalDiseaseanimal tissues that maintain cell structure through production. No matter the source method, plant proteins‚Äîwhich are almost always processedProcessing in some way‚Äîcan be easily combined in various ways. The nutritionalNutrition content of cultured meat may not be a significant concern because the nutritionalNutrition composition of these foods can be modified, enriched, and fortified in the lab to match the foods found naturally (Sergelidis 2019). But challenges remain. Will consumers accept these novel foods (Bryant and Barnett 2019)? History shows that consumers are often suspicious of unnatural foods, at least initially (Chriki and Hocquette 2020). Other concerns include cost, taste, sustainabilitySustainability, and safety.

ReformulationReformulation is the process of altering a food or beverage product‚Äôs processingProcessing or composition to improve the product‚Äôs health profile or to reduce the content of harmful nutrients or ingredients (Scott et al. 2017). ReformulationReformulation encompasses both removing negative ingredients and nutrients, as well as adding positive ones to foods ranging from minimally to highly processedProcessingfoods. ReformulationReformulation may be undertaken for reasons unrelated to better public health outcomes via improved nutritionNutrition. Companies can, and do, reformulate products for a variety of other reasons, including to increase nutrient density; to improve shelf-life, safety, and taste; to reduce costs; and to otherwise improve profitability (Box 7).

sec.title: Box 7: Reformulation, fortification, and functionalization‚Äîincentivizing old innovations
sec.p: There has been increased attention given to the health impacts of highly processedProcessing foods that are high in salt, added sugar, saturated and trans fatsMacronutrientsFat(s), and energy density, and low in fiber, protein, and micronutrients, and that also contribute to, and are associated with, overweightMalnutritionobesity, obesity, and non-communicableDiseasenon-communicable diseases (Vandevijvere et al. 2019; Monteiro et al. 2013; Baker and Friel 2016; Baker et al. 2020; Hall, n.d.). Sub-optimal dietary outcomes have stimulated governmental nutritionNutrition policies to strive to reduce the intake of salt, added sugar, and unhealthyDiet(s)unhealthyfatsMacronutrientsFat(s). Alongside promoting consumption of fresh nutritious foods (e.g., fruitsFruits, vegetablesVegetables, and whole grainsCereals), the reformulationReformulation, fortification, or functionalizationof processedProcessing foods may help improve diets in every food systemFoodsystems. Can reduced processingProcessing of food‚Äîsuch as grinding, millingProcessing, and the removal of key nutrients‚Äîto promote more whole foods decrease the need to add back nutrients post-processing and reduce environmental footprints of the process overall (Seferidi et al. 2020)? The innovations in this space are less around food science than around aligning incentives.

ReformulationReformulation of foods can remove negative nutrients and/or add positive nutrients. Currently, it consists mainly of reducing the amount of salt, added sugar, saturated and trans fatsMacronutrientsFat(s), and the energy density in processedProcessing foods, largely to produce niche products to expand the range of consumer choice (Buttriss 2013). ReformulationReformulation can also increase healthy components, such as fiber, protein, micronutrients, or phytochemicals. Fortification adds essential vitaminsMicronutrientsvitamins and mineralsMicronutrientsminerals to commonly consumed foods such as maizeCereals flour, edible oil, riceCereals, salt, and wheatCereals flour. It can also replace micronutrients lost during processingProcessing, such as with cerealsCereals, or address micronutrient deficienciesMicronutrientsdeficiencies in the population, as with iodized salt (Das et al. 2019; Salam et al. 2019). Functionalization involves adding other beneficial ingredients that are specifically targeted to improve health (phytochemicals, pro-biotics, etc.).

While the main research focusing on reformulationReformulation, fortification, and/or functionalization concerns these processes‚Äô potential to improve nutritionNutrition and health, the main current industrialFortificationindustrial practices are for other, commercial purposes: decreasing costs, meeting changing consumer preferences, tapping into new consumer markets to boost sales or the company‚Äôs public image, improving food safetyFoodsafetyand preservationProcessing, and/or complying with governmentGovernment(s) regulations, where they exist).

Inducing more reformulationReformulation using existing technologies to promote healthyDiet(s)healthy diets likely requires shifting incentives through labeling requirements, taxesTaxes, and/or regulatory constraints. Clear consumer signaling through labeling can incentivize companies to reformulate, particularly if labels carry warnings. Simple, easy-to-interpret front-of-pack labels that include stars, traffic lights, or other assessments of nutritionNutrition and health are increasingly effective and used in Chile, AustraliaAustralia, New Zealand, and the US, among others (Reyes et al. 2019; Chantal et al. 2017; Hersey et al. 2013; Jones et al. 2019). Companies reformulate products in order to avoid a low rating or a warning label (Vandevijvere and Vanderlee 2019).

So-called ‚Äúsin taxes‚Äù are another tool. National and local taxesTaxes on sugar-sweetened beverages (SSB) and other energy-dense foods have been introduced in several countries (Hagenaars). In Mexico, Saudi Arabia, and Chile, SSB taxesTaxes were associated with an 8‚Äì24 percent reduction in purchases (Taillie et al. 2020). Sin taxesTaxes often face strenuous corporate resistance, however (Sainsbury et al. 2020).

National bans of certain ingredients (e.g., trans fatsMacronutrientsFat(s) or salt) or requirements of nutrients in specific food vehicles (e.g., fortification of flours, oil, or saltFortificationsalt) also shift industry incentives to adjust the product portfolio (Fanzo and McLaren 2020). Where private industry standards cannot converge around beneficial practices‚Äîas in the case of salt iodization in the US, for example‚ÄîgovernmentGovernment(s) regulatory standards may be necessary.

Ultimately, food industry actors need incentives‚Äîpositive or negative‚Äîto reformulate foods not only in response to consumer preferences that can be manipulated through marketing, but equally, to improve consumer nutritionNutrition and health, as well as environmental sustainabilitySustainability in the face of the climate crisis. The food industry responds to new demands to make premium or superior products, as well as continual demands to make lower-cost products.

Once food moves through supply chainsValue chains, innovations attempt to maintain or improve quality and ensure those foods are accessible and affordable. For at least 3 billion people, healthy foods remain unaffordable (Hirvonen et al. 2020; Headey and Alderman 2019; Bai et al. 2020; FAO 2020). The bitter irony is that affordable, healthyDiet(s)healthy diets are especially inaccessible to the ruralRural poor, who are most likely to work in AFSsAgri-food systems (AFS). For example, 63‚Äì76 percent of India‚Äôs ruralRural poor could not afford a recommended diet in 2011 (Raghunathan et al. 2020). Globally, Bai et al. (2020) find that the minimum cost of a nutritious diet relative to household per capita expenditures falls with per capita incomeIncome, access to electricity, and proximity to a city.

Food consumption can be influenced by ensuring nutritious foods are cheaper and unhealthyDiet(s)unhealthy foods are more expensive (Eyles et al. 2012; Thow et al. 2014). TaxesTaxesand subsidiesSubsidiescan be used to shape prices and change dietary intake. For example, taxesTaxes on SSBs can lead to a 20‚Äì50 percent reduction in consumption, while the subsidiesSubsidiesfor fruitsFruitsand vegetablesVegetables can lead to a 10‚Äì30 percent increase in consumption (Thow et al. 2014). However, taxesTaxes can be regressive, imposing greater economic burdens on the poor than on the wealthy. Combining taxesTaxes with healthy food subsidiesSubsidies‚Äîwhich have been far less common‚Äîcould be one mechanism to mitigate the regressivity by allowing for populations to switch to healthier products without additional costs (Thow et al. 2010).

Nonmanipulable tracking and traceabilityTraceability using molecular markers, biomarkers, micro sensorsDigital technologiessensors, regulationFoodregulation, etc., can also improve food safetyFoodsafety and help producers and intermediaries capture consumer valuation of foods‚Äô credence attributes. However, significant challenges and technical barriers must still be overcome. Food safetyFoodsafety tracking and traceabilityTraceability systems are probably one of the best developed solutions in this domain in most high-incomeIncome countries. However, much of the Global South still lacks sufficient safety tracking and traceabilityTraceability, with serious consequences, such as outbreaks of pathogenic bacteria or viruses, and chemical contaminations.

Block chainTraceability technology in agriculture and food supplyFoodsupply chains has gained much attention recently. Is this a solution for nonmanipulable traceabilityTraceability? Significant challenges with this still-emerging technology exist around accessibility, governance, technical aspects (e.g., energy demands), policies, and regulatory frameworks (Kamilaris et al. 2019; Behnke and Janssen 2020). As with every innovationTechnologyinnovation, we need to maximize the technology readinessTechnologyreadiness level up to 9 (i.e., the actual system proven in an operational environment) before reaching strong conclusions, and we must learn from the ongoing innovation cycle.

Precision or personalized nutrition (PN) is an approach to addressing current nutritionNutrition problems using large quantities of detailed and multidimensional metabolic and health data to better understand the range of how human metabolism responds to diet. PN relies on a wide range of tools, including genomics, metabolomics, microbiomics, phenotyping, high-throughput analytical chemistry techniques, longitudinal tracking using body sensorsDigital technologiessensors, informatics, data scienceDigital technologiesmachine learning, and education and behavioral interventions to arrive at highly personalized and targeted dietary guidance and interventions (O‚ÄôSullivan et al. 2018).

Although many studies have been performed to identify genetic factors that explain the variabilityClimatevariability in metabolic response to specific diets, most findings are still relatively far from translatable for guidance. However, there are examples of findings that have already translated into guidance‚Äîincluding hypolactasia diagnosis, the ruling out of celiac disease, or phenylketonuria screening‚Äîwhich have led to tailored nutritionalNutrition advice (avoiding lactose, gluten, and phenylalanine-containing products for at-risk individuals) based on genetics (de Toro-Mart√≠n et al. 2017).

Individualized approaches to PN remain expensive, though, and therefore may not be feasible in all settings due to budget constraints. Cost is a big reason why PN has thus far been targeted mainly to high-incomeIncome environments, where individuals face very different nutritional challenges than do those in resource-poor settings. Moreover, PN is not a substitute for public health infrastructureInfrastructureaddressing underlying social, political, and economic inequities that are known drivers of population health outcomes. There is much work to do in removing existing barriers (social, economic, political) to adequate diets. PN can fine tune once barriers are removed. Global populations may be diverse, so the call for diversified approaches to addressing diet-driven health problems makes sense on its face. But are individual differences in responses to diets really a significant driver of the global burden of diet-related disease? Thus far there is insufficient evidence that genotype-specific recommendations from direct-to-consumer genetic testing companies perform any better than ‚Äúone-size-fits-all‚Äù recommendations (Loos 2019). For example, one recent study attempting to predict who would respond to dietary supplements of omega-3 fatty acids did not perform well out of sample (Marcotte et al. 2019). A second study examining the effects of dietary linoleic acid found an effect (Lankinen et al. 2019), but the magnitude was too small to be of use in precision nutritionNutrition (de Roos et al. 2019). While there is significant enthusiasm for PN-based methods, we do not yet see this as a high-potential area.
